Murder.title: Republic v Kalii (Murder Case 7 of 2017)
Murder.facts: The accused, Kalii, was charged with the murder of one Damaris Wanjiru during a domestic dispute. Witnesses found the deceased with fatal stab wounds. The accused was arrested near the scene shortly after the incident.
Murder.Legal_Principle: A prima facie case was established under Section 306(2) of the Criminal Procedure Code. Murder requires proof of unlawful killing with malice aforethought under Section 203 of the Penal Code.

Murder.title: Republic v ENW (Murder Case 38 of 2020)
Murder.facts: ENW was charged with the murder of a minor. Evidence included medical reports and witness testimony from the guardian. The accused denied involvement.
Murder.Legal_Principle: The court held that to secure a conviction under Section 203 of the Penal Code, the prosecution must prove death, unlawful act, and malice aforethought.

Murder.title: Republic v Loriu (Murder Case 32 of 2017)
Murder.facts: The accused was alleged to have struck the deceased with a blunt object during a family conflict. The postmortem revealed head trauma.
Murder.Legal_Principle: The court emphasized the need to connect the accused with the weapon and intent to kill under Section 203.

Murder.title: Republic v Wekesa (Murder Case E023 of 2021)
Murder.facts: Wekesa allegedly killed the victim following a land boundary dispute. Eyewitnesses testified seeing Wekesa strike the victim with a machete.
Murder.Legal_Principle: Court ruled there was sufficient evidence to place the accused on their defense under Section 306 of the CPC.

Murder.title: Republic v Otieno (Criminal Case (Murder) E033 of 2022)
Murder.facts: Otieno was charged after fatally stabbing a neighbor. A bloodstained knife was recovered at the scene.
Murder.Legal_Principle: The ruling confirmed that malice aforethought was inferable from the use of a deadly weapon aimed at a vital organ.

Murder.title: Republic v Chebonya (Criminal Case E050 (Murder) of 2023)
Murder.facts: Chebonya was accused of strangling his spouse. Circumstantial evidence and witness testimony placed him at the crime scene.
Murder.Legal_Principle: Court found that circumstantial evidence, if consistent and excluding other hypotheses, could lead to conviction.

Murder.title: Republic v Musau & another (Murder Case 072 of 2023)
Murder.facts: The two accused persons were jointly charged with killing a matatu driver over a fare dispute. CCTV footage supported the prosecution.
Murder.Legal_Principle: Joint enterprise and common intention principles applied under Section 21 of the Penal Code.

Murder.title: Republic v Osunga (Criminal Case (Murder) E027 of 2024)
Murder.facts: David Odhiambo Osunga was charged with killing his stepbrother after a domestic quarrel escalated.
Murder.Legal_Principle: The use of excessive force and prior threats contributed to a finding of malice aforethought.

Murder.title: Republic v Daniel Anyango Omoyo (Murder Case 2 of 2012)
Murder.facts: Daniel Anyango Omoyo was accused of stabbing a relative during a drinking incident. The postmortem report confirmed internal bleeding.
Murder.Legal_Principle: Intent to kill may be inferred from the nature and location of the injury and the weapon used.

Murder.title: Republic v Otieno (Criminal Case (Murder) E004 of 2023)
Murder.facts: The accused, Martin Omondi Otieno, was charged with the murder of a civilian following an altercation. Witnesses testified to hearing a commotion before discovering the deceased. A bloodstained weapon was recovered at the scene.
Murder.Legal_Principle: The court evaluated whether the prosecution had proven malice aforethought through evidence of intent, motive, and the nature of the weapon used.

Murder.title: Republic v Otieno (Criminal Case (Murder) E021‘B’ of 2022)
Murder.facts: John Okinyo Otieno was accused of stabbing a relative during a domestic dispute. Medical evidence confirmed multiple fatal stab wounds to the torso.
Murder.Legal_Principle: The court emphasized that proof of intent and the use of a lethal weapon supported a finding of malice aforethought.

Murder.title: Republic v Mwaniki & 4 others (Murder Case 10 of 2023)
Murder.facts: The accused were jointly charged with the killing of a businessman. Surveillance and witness testimonies linked them to the crime scene.
Murder.Legal_Principle: The doctrine of common intention under Section 21 of the Penal Code was applied due to coordinated actions leading to the murder.

Murder.title: Republic v Lepereen Lenengwesi (Murder Case 64 of 2010)
Murder.facts: The accused was charged with the murder of his neighbor following a land dispute. The body was discovered with multiple blunt-force injuries.
Murder.Legal_Principle: The court held that prior threats and witness evidence demonstrated premeditation, fulfilling the test for malice aforethought.

Murder.title: Wambua Kioko v Republic (Murder Case 13 of 2009)
Murder.facts: The appellant was charged with the murder of his spouse after a domestic disagreement. He sought to challenge the admissibility of his confession.
Murder.Legal_Principle: The court ruled on the admissibility of confessions and reiterated that such statements must be voluntary to support conviction.

Murder.title: Republic v James Macharia Gatwiku (Murder Case 12 of 2015)
Murder.facts: The accused was suspected of murdering a farm worker. The prosecution relied heavily on circumstantial evidence and last seen theory.
Murder.Legal_Principle: The court noted that circumstantial evidence must form a complete chain and point exclusively to the guilt of the accused.

Murder.title: Republic v Otieno (Criminal Case (Murder) E016 of 2022)
Murder.facts: Francis Stephen Otieno was accused of murdering a colleague during a drunken altercation. A knife was found concealed in the compound.
Murder.Legal_Principle: The court relied on medical reports and eyewitness accounts to infer the accused's intent and responsibility.

Murder.title: Republic v Onono (Criminal Case (Murder) E050 of 2024)
Murder.facts: The accused was originally charged with murder but entered a plea bargain agreement. The victim had suffered fatal head injuries during an assault.
Murder.Legal_Principle: The court discussed the scope and legality of plea bargaining under Kenyan law and reduced the charge accordingly.

Murder.case_name: Republic v Maware alias Moi & 2 others
Murder.court: High Court of Kenya at Siaya
Murder.facts: The accused persons including Maware alias Moi were charged with murder. The ruling addressed admissibility and sufficiency of evidence presented.
Murder.Legal_Principle: An accused can only be committed for trial if the prosecution establishes a prima facie case at committal stage.

Murder.facts: Everlyne Martha Opicho was charged with the offence of murder in Criminal (Murder) Case No. 9 of 2017.
Murder.Legal_Principle: For murder to be proved, malice aforethought must be established through conduct or surrounding circumstances.

Murder.case_name: Republic v Stephen Lelei & Fredrick Leliman
Murder.facts: The accused, Stephen Lelei and Fredrick Leliman, were jointly charged with murder in Case No. 16 of 2020.
Murder.Legal_Principle: Where multiple accused are charged jointly, each individual’s conduct must be analyzed independently to determine participation in the crime.

Murder.court: High Court of Kenya at Siaya
Murder.facts: Fabian Owiti Miruka and Victor Odhiambo Miruka were charged with murder in Criminal Case E021 ‘A’ of 2022.
Murder.Legal_Principle: Circumstantial evidence must exclude any reasonable hypothesis of innocence and be consistent with the accused’s guilt.

Murder.court: High Court of Kenya at Kisii
Murder.facts: The accused was arraigned on 23 February 2005 for murder and the ruling discusses preliminary matters.
Murder.Legal_Principle: Where evidence is solely circumstantial, the chain must be complete and point irresistibly to the accused.

Murder.court: High Court of Kenya at Kerugoya
Murder.facts: The accused, Stephen Wachira Wangara, was charged with murder contrary to Section 203 as read with Section 204 of the Penal Code.
Murder.Legal_Principle: Mental status of the accused must be considered when the defense of insanity is raised.

Murder.court: High Court of Kenya at Nakuru
Murder.facts: Jackson Kimeli Koech fled after the incident, indicating knowledge of having murdered the deceased.
Murder.Legal_Principle: Flight from the scene can be indicative of guilt when corroborated by other evidence.

Murder.court: High Court of Kenya at Kerugoya
Murder.facts: Father and son were charged with the murder of EWR, the wife and mother respectively.
Murder.Legal_Principle: Motive and domestic relationships can establish context in homicide cases but must be supported by concrete evidence.

Murder.court: High Court of Kenya at Siaya
Murder.facts: Samwel Ojwang Onyango was charged with the offence of murder in Case No. 7 of 2019.
Murder.Legal_Principle: Eyewitness testimony must be consistent and credible to support a conviction in murder trials.

Murder.court: High Court of Kenya at Naivasha
Murder.facts: The accused claimed he was framed for the deceased's murder in Case No. 6 of 2014.
Murder.Legal_Principle: An accused person bears no burden to prove innocence; the prosecution must prove guilt beyond reasonable doubt.

Murder.case_name: Republic v Henry Nyabuto Arori & Haron Nyabuka Arori
Murder.court: High Court of Kenya at Kisii
Murder.facts: The accused, Henry Nyabuto Arori and Haron Nyabuka Arori, were charged with murdering their brother John Mose Nyangau on 18 May 2015. The deceased was attacked with a panga and later died while undergoing treatment. However, the postmortem indicated the fatal injuries occurred on 1 June 2015, not 18 May. The prosecution's witnesses (PW1, PW2, and PW3) only testified about the first assault on 18 May. There was no witness testimony linking the accused to the second, fatal assault. The court concluded there was insufficient evidence to connect the accused to the murder.
Murder.Legal_Principle: Where the prosecution fails to prove beyond reasonable doubt that the injuries causing death were inflicted by the accused, a conviction for murder cannot stand. Mere suspicion, prior charges, or previous altercations without direct evidence of causation are insufficient. The burden of proof lies entirely on the prosecution, and the presumption of innocence must be upheld unless fully rebutted.

Murder.case_name: Francis Karioko Muruatetu & Another v Republic; Katiba Institute & 5 others (Amicus Curiae)
Murder.judge: Chief Justice David Maraga, Justices Ibrahim, Ojwang, Wanjala, Njoki
Murder.facts: Petitioners challenged the constitutionality of the mandatory death sentence for murder under Section 204 of the Penal Code, arguing it violated the right to fair trial and human dignity.
Murder.Legal_Principle: Mandatory death penalty for murder is unconstitutional. Courts must individualize sentencing by considering mitigating/aggravating factors.

Murder.facts: Defendants charged with murder; court emphasized that a conviction under Section 203 of the Penal Code must be based on conclusive evidence.
Murder.Legal_Principle: Murder convictions require proof beyond reasonable doubt; courts cannot presume guilt solely on charges.

Murder.facts: Accused jointly charged with murder in Baringo County under Section 203 of the Penal Code.
Murder.Legal_Principle: Joint murder charges require evidence of shared intent or action under Section 21 of the Penal Code.

Murder.facts: Accused charged with murder in Koibatek Sub-County, Baringo County.
Murder.Legal_Principle: Prosecution must prove all elements of murder (actus reus and mens rea) under Section 203 of the Penal Code.

Murder.case_name: Muruatetu & Another v Republic; Katiba Institute & 4 others (Amicus Curiae)
Murder.facts: Clarification of the 2017 Muruatetu judgment regarding resentencing of death row convicts.
Murder.Legal_Principle: All murder convicts sentenced under the mandatory death penalty are entitled to resentencing hearings.

Murder.facts: Appellant's murder charge reduced to manslaughter after plea agreement.
Murder.Legal_Principle: Plea bargaining is permissible in murder cases if evidence supports a lesser charge.

Murder.facts: Appellant convicted of murder and sentenced to death; appealed based on evidence.
Murder.Legal_Principle: Circumstantial evidence can sustain a murder conviction if it conclusively points to guilt.

Theft.case_name: Mwikali v Flame Tree Africa Limited
Theft.facts: The claimant was summarily dismissed following a workplace theft. The employer argued she failed to cooperate with internal investigations, insurance, and police inquiries. Her refusal was deemed insubordination and gross misconduct.
Theft.Legal_Principle: An employee’s failure to cooperate in post-incident investigations, especially involving theft, may lawfully justify summary dismissal under principles of gross misconduct if proper procedure is followed.

Theft.case_name: Rono v Republic
Theft.facts: The appellant had reported a theft incident under volatile circumstances. The court questioned the credibility of the report and found contradictions in the theft allegation timeline.
Theft.Legal_Principle: Where an accused’s version of events in a theft case is inconsistent or unsubstantiated by objective evidence, a court may reject the defense and uphold conviction if prosecution evidence is credible.

Theft.case_name: Galaxy Paints Company Ltd v Falcon Guards Ltd
Theft.facts: The trial court had found that burglary and theft occurred. The appellant’s failure to report the incident weakened their claim of due diligence in the aftermath.
Theft.Legal_Principle: Failure to report a theft or burglary in a timely manner may affect liability and credibility in commercial or insurance disputes concerning loss recovery.

Theft.case_name: Kirungi v Republic
Theft.facts: The prosecution successfully proved the charge of theft. The object taken met the criteria under section 268 of the Penal Code as ‘capable of being stolen’.
Theft.Legal_Principle: To prove theft, the prosecution must establish that the item was capable of being stolen and that the taking met all statutory elements under section 268 of the Penal Code.

Theft.case_name: In re Complaint Against Nelson Andayi Havi Advocate
Theft.Legal_Principle: Public commentary on legal matters by advocates must maintain decorum. Legal definitions of theft apply equally regardless of gender or status.

Theft.case_name: Njenga v Republic
Theft.facts: The accused was alleged to have rejected advances, prompting a false theft accusation. The court noted that theft is a foundational ingredient of robbery with violence.
Theft.Legal_Principle: In robbery with violence, theft is the primary component, and must be accompanied by actual or threatened violence immediately before, during, or after the taking.

Theft.case_name: Republic v Basweti
Theft.facts: Testimony revealed that the deceased had a history of disciplinary issues including theft. The accused was made aware of a theft report just prior to the incident.
Theft.Legal_Principle: Prior misconduct or history of theft by a victim may be relevant to motive but cannot justify retaliatory violence. Every charge must be independently proven.

Theft.case_name: Republic v Barno & 5 others; Sayan Investments Ltd (Victim)
Theft.facts: The court addressed the capacity of juristic persons like companies to be victims of crimes, including theft.
Theft.Legal_Principle: Companies and other juristic persons are recognized under Kenyan law as capable of being victims of theft and related economic crimes.

Theft.case_name: Joseph Kaberia Kahinga & others v Attorney General
Theft.facts: The court distinguished between theft and robbery. Theft became robbery where violence was used to complete or escape with the stolen item.
Theft.Legal_Principle: Under section 295 of the Penal Code, theft becomes robbery if accompanied by actual violence, intimidation, or threat immediately before or after the act.

Theft.case_name: Macharia v Republic
Theft.facts: The appellant was convicted of vehicle theft. The court affirmed the sufficiency of evidence proving theft and possession contrary to section 278A of the Penal Code.
Theft.Legal_Principle: In cases of theft of motor vehicles, credible witness testimony and possession of the stolen item can establish guilt under section 278A of the Penal Code.

Theft.case_name: Kenya Power & Lighting Company Limited v Aggrey Lukorito Wasike
Theft.facts: Disciplinary hearing confirmed attempted theft allegations against employee. Employer denied actual theft occurred.
Theft.Legal_Principle: Employers must prove theft allegations with concrete evidence; attempted theft requires intent demonstration.

Theft.case_name: Kenya Plantation and Agricultural Workers Union v Unilever Tea Kenya Limited
Theft.facts: Employee suspected of participating in a year-long theft syndicate involving paper sacks. Investigations linked her to the thefts.
Theft.Legal_Principle: Suspicion of theft must be reasonable and backed by evidence for disciplinary action.

Theft.case_name: Koros v Republic
Theft.facts: Appeal against conviction for housebreaking and theft. Police investigations discredited the theft allegations.
Theft.Legal_Principle: Theft convictions require proof of unlawful taking; investigations must be thorough and credible.

Theft.case_name: Simon Mbithi Mbane v Inter Security Services Limited
Theft.facts: Employee charged with theft after being suspected of involvement. Employer retained him despite suspicions.
Theft.Legal_Principle: Suspicion alone cannot justify termination; proof of theft is required.

Theft.case_name: Equity Bank Limited v Wells Fargo Limited
Theft.facts: Dispute over liability for theft of cash aboard an aircraft during transit. Theft occurred while cash was physically on the plane.
Theft.Legal_Principle: Contractual liability for theft depends on custody/control of goods at the time of theft.

Theft.case_name: Hakika Transport Services Limited v Juma
Theft.facts: Employee dismissed for allegedly facilitating theft of a tyre. Theft occurred in his absence.
Theft.Legal_Principle: Employers must prove active involvement in theft; mere suspicion is insufficient for dismissal.

Theft.case_name: Uhuru Highway Development Limited v Central Bank of Kenya & Others
Theft.facts: Case involved evidence of fraud and theft, including a manager arrested for hotel theft.
Theft.Legal_Principle: Theft allegations in commercial disputes require forensic evidence for liability.

Theft.case_name: Republic v Commissioner for Cooperative Development & 13 Others
Theft.citation: [2025] KEHC 8944 (KLR), Judicial Review Application E162 of 2024
Theft.facts: Audit revealed mismanagement and theft at KUSCCO cooperative.
Theft.principle: Institutional theft must be proven through audits and financial trails.

Theft.case_name: Joseph Nzioka v Smart Coatings Limited
Theft.facts: Employee accused of theft, arrested, and charged. Claimed wrongful accusation.
Theft.Legal_Principle: Arrest for theft without evidence violates labor rights.

Theft.case_name: Gichuhi v Republic
Theft.facts: Witness testified about theft based on hearsay; no direct evidence presented.
Theft.Legal_Principle: Hearsay evidence is inadmissible for proving theft; direct witness accounts required.

Theft.case_name: Gabriel Kamau Njoroge v Republic
Theft.facts: Appeal against robbery conviction which included theft elements. Court evaluated whether defense raised reasonable doubt.
Theft.Legal_Principle: Robbery convictions require proof of theft as a core element under the Penal Code.

Theft.case_name: Mwabaka v Bungoma Branch Manager, Kenya Farmers Association Limited & another
Theft.facts: Employee dismissed for alleged theft without show-cause hearing. Employer admitted theft reports but process contested.
Theft.Legal_Principle: Dismissals for theft require procedural fairness including right to be heard.

Theft.case_name: Mtana Lewa v Kahindi Ngala Mwagandi
Theft.facts: Dispute where adverse possession was analogized to 'land theft' in arguments.
Theft.Legal_Principle: Adverse possession claims distinct from criminal theft; requires open possession.

Theft.case_name: Republic & another v Auctioneers Licensing Board; Mutisya (Interested Party)
Theft.facts: Case alleging unlawful auctioneering practices described as 'theft of private property'.
Theft.Legal_Principle: Auctioneers must comply with lawful procedures to avoid conversion/theft claims.

Theft.case_name: Boniface Francis Mwangi v B.O.M. Iyego Secondary School
Theft.facts: Teacher accused of theft of school items; contested arrest and dismissal.
Theft.Legal_Principle: Employer bears burden of proof in theft-related terminations.

Theft.case_name: Jeremiah Oloo Odira v Republic
Theft.facts: Robbery case where court examined whether theft element was proven.
Theft.Legal_Principle: Theft is a prerequisite component for robbery convictions under Section 296 Penal Code.

Theft.case_name: Wafula v Republic
Theft.facts: Guilty plea for burglary and theft charges under Penal Code.
Theft.Legal_Principle: Burglary with theft requires proof of unlawful entry and appropriation.

Theft.case_name: Dima Denge Dima & Others v Republic
Theft.facts: Robbery appeal focusing on theft definition within robbery context.
Theft.Legal_Principle: Robbery = Theft + Violence/Intimidation at time of taking.

Theft.case_name: Antiphace Herman v Republic
Theft.facts: Stock theft conviction appeal; defendant denied involvement.
Theft.Legal_Principle: Stock theft under Penal Code requires proof of unlawful taking of animals.

Theft.case_name: Kariuki v New Palea Wholesalers Limited
Theft.facts: Employee alleged to be involved in theft, leading to humiliation.
Theft.Legal_Principle: Unproven theft allegations may constitute workplace harassment.

Robbery.case_name: Katiba Institute v Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions & 5 others
Robbery.court: High Court (Constitutional and Human Rights Division)
Robbery.facts: Constitutional petition challenging prosecution practices for robbery with violence cases post-March 2018.
Robbery.principle: Examines procedural fairness in robbery with violence charges under Section 296(2) Penal Code.

Robbery.citation: Criminal Miscellaneous Application E050 of 2024 [2025] KEHC 5438 (KLR)
Robbery.facts: Applicants convicted of robbery with violence under Section 296(2); challenged sentencing constitutionality.
Robbery.principle: Death penalty for robbery with violence remains constitutional per Muruatetu II clarification.

Robbery.case_name: Joseph Kaberia Kahinga & 11 others v Attorney General
Robbery.facts: Challenge to distinction between simple robbery (Section 295) and aggravated robbery (Section 296(2)).
Robbery.principle: All robbery requires theft/extortion; violence elevates it to Section 296(2).

Robbery.case_name: Dima Denge Dima & Others v Republic
Robbery.facts: Appeal against robbery with violence conviction under Section 295 Penal Code.
Robbery.principle: Violence/threat must coincide with theft for robbery under Section 295.

Robbery.facts: Charge amended from theft to robbery with violence mid-trial; procedural challenge.
Robbery.principle: Amendment of charges must not prejudice accused; robbery requires proof of violence.

Robbery.case_name: Reuben Taabu Anjononi & 2 others v Republic
Robbery.facts: Capital robbery appeal under repealed statute; examined violence requirements.
Robbery.principle: Capital robbery required proof of violence causing death under old law.

Robbery.facts: Charge of capital robbery under Section 296(2); convicted of simple robbery under Section 295.
Robbery.principle: Court may convict for lesser offense (Section 295) if violence not proven.

Robbery.facts: Appeal against robbery conviction; examined timing of violence relative to theft.
Robbery.principle: Violence 'immediately before/after' theft satisfies Section 296(2).

Robbery.case_name: Muruatetu & another v Republic; Katiba Institute & 4 others (Amicus Curiae)
Robbery.facts: Clarified Muruatetu I applicability to robbery with violence (Section 296(2)) sentencing.
Robbery.principle: Mandatory death penalty unconstitutional; applies to robbery with violence cases.

Robbery.facts: Interpretation of 'violence' elements under Section 296(2) Penal Code.
Robbery.principle: Single violent element suffices for robbery with violence conviction.

Robbery.facts: Appeal involving charges of murder and robbery with violence under Section 296(2) Penal Code.
Robbery.principle: Distinction between murder (Section 203) and robbery with violence (Section 296(2)) charges.

Robbery.facts: Appeal against robbery with violence conviction; questioned timing of robbery (7:30pm).
Robbery.principle: Time of day is not determinative in proving robbery under Section 296(2).

Robbery.facts: Revision of robbery with violence conviction from Gatundu Chief Magistrate's Court.
Robbery.principle: High Court's supervisory role over subordinate courts in robbery cases.

Robbery.facts: Case involving two separate robbery incidents; only one subject of appeal.
Robbery.principle: Multiple robberies require separate evidential analysis under Section 295.

Robbery.facts: Appeal against robbery conviction involving theft of military binoculars.
Robbery.principle: Value of stolen items irrelevant for robbery with violence under Section 296(2).

Robbery.case_name: Michael Kathewa Laichena & another v Republic
Robbery.facts: Challenge to mandatory death penalty for robbery with violence.
Robbery.principle: Section 296(2) creates aggravated form of robbery under Section 295.

Robbery.facts: Appeal against robbery with violence conviction; challenged evidentiary nexus.
Robbery.principle: Direct evidence required to connect accused to robbery under Section 296(2).

Robbery.facts: Applicability of Muruatetu principles to robbery with violence cases.
Robbery.principle: Muruatetu sentencing discretion doesn't automatically apply to Section 296(2).

Robbery.case_name: Equity Bank Limited v Wells Fargo Limited
Robbery.facts: Civil suit arising from armed robbery during cash transit.
Robbery.principle: Security protocols critical in determining liability for robbery losses.

Robbery.citation: Miscellaneous Criminal Application E003 of 2022 [2025] KEHC 9165 (KLR)
Robbery.facts: Resentencing application for robbery with violence under Section 296(2).
Robbery.principle: Degree of violence considered in resentencing post-Muruatetu.

Robbery.facts: Appeal against robbery with violence conviction under Section 296(2); challenged identification evidence and application of recent possession doctrine.
Robbery.principle: Positive identification is crucial in robbery cases; recent possession alone may not suffice for Section 296(2) conviction.

Robbery.facts: Appeal from Bungoma Chief Magistrate's Court conviction for robbery with violence under Sections 295/296(2).
Robbery.principle: Distinction between simple robbery (Section 295) and aggravated robbery (Section 296(2)) must be clearly pleaded.

Robbery.facts: Appeal against robbery conviction; examined complainant's distressed state during incident.
Robbery.principle: Victim's condition during robbery may corroborate violence element under Section 296(2).

Robbery.facts: Appeal against robbery with violence conviction involving Kshs.9,000 theft with beating.
Robbery.principle: Section 296(2) requires proof of: (1) theft, (2) violence/threats, (3) multiple perpetrators.

Robbery.facts: Appeal against convictions for both capital robbery (Section 296(2)) and simple robbery (Section 295).
Robbery.principle: Multiple robbery counts require separate proof of violence elements for Section 296(2).

Robbery.facts: Revision of two-count robbery conviction from Voi Senior Principal Magistrate's Court.
Robbery.principle: Concurrent sentences for multiple robberies subject to High Court revision.

Robbery.facts: Appeal emphasizing three elements of Section 296(2): theft, violence, and multiple perpetrators.
Robbery.principle: Presence of >1 person during robbery elevates offense to Section 296(2).

Robbery.facts: Appeal against Section 296(2) conviction; examined distinction from simple robbery.
Robbery.principle: Violence must accompany theft to constitute robbery with violence under Section 296(2).

Robbery.citation: Miscellaneous Criminal Application E052 of 2024 [2025] KEHC 8279 (KLR)
Robbery.facts: Application challenging 7-year sentence for robbery conviction.
Robbery.principle: Sentencing discretion applies post-Muruatetu even for non-capital robberies.

Robbery.facts: Appeal involving robbery with violence where lantern lighting aided identification.
Robbery.principle: Adequate lighting conditions critical for reliable identification in robbery cases.

Assault.facts: Probation report review for offender serving 3-year sentence for assault.
Assault.principle: Probation reports considered in sentencing for assault cases.

Assault.facts: Case involving penetrative sexual assault causing urinary tract infection.
Assault.principle: Medical evidence crucial in proving sexual assault cases.

Assault.case_name: Alfred Mincha Ndubi v County Assembly Nyamira County
Assault.facts: Employment dispute with pending assault case before Chief Magistrate's Court.
Assault.principle: Parallel civil and criminal proceedings (assault) permitted.

Assault.case_name: Walala v Guardian Coach Limited & another
Assault.citation: Judicial Review Application E065 of 2024 [2025] KEELRC 792 (KLR)
Assault.facts: Workplace altercation with assault allegations pending in Busia Law Courts.
Assault.principle: Employment disputes may be stayed pending criminal assault proceedings.

Assault.facts: Child protection case involving alleged sexual assault investigations.
Assault.principle: Special protections apply in sexual assault cases involving minors.

Assault.facts: Conviction for assault causing actual bodily harm under Section 251 Penal Code.
Assault.principle: Section 251 requires proof of physical harm for assault conviction.

Assault.facts: Appeal against conviction for indecent assault under Section 140 of the Penal Code.
Assault.principle: Indecent assault requires proof of unlawful sexual contact without consent.

Assault.case_name: Kasuki t/a Glory Secondary School & 2 others v County Government of Kajiado & 2 others
Assault.facts: Land dispute involving allegations of assault as a criminal matter.
Assault.principle: Assault allegations in civil cases require police reports for credibility.

Assault.case_name: J.P. Machira t/a Machira & Co Advocates v East African Standard Ltd
Assault.facts: Defamation case involving allegations of assault during altercation.
Assault.principle: Media reports of assault require factual verification to avoid defamation.

Assault.facts: Case examining lawful vs unlawful assault under Section 234 Penal Code.
Assault.principle: Lawful assault must fall within statutory exceptions (self-defense, etc.).

Assault.facts: Constitutional petition alleging assault on deceased's property rights.
Assault.principle: State actions violating property rights may constitute constitutional assault.

Assault.case_name: Bonaya Tutu Ipu & another v Republic
Assault.facts: Appeal against murder conviction involving vicious assault on deceased.
Assault.principle: Severity of assault may prove malice aforethought for murder.

Assault.case_name: Joseph Kaberia Kahinga & 11 others v Attorney General
Assault.facts: Constitutional petition examining definition of assault in Penal Code.
Assault.principle: Assault under Kenyan law follows common law principles (apprehension of harm).

Assault.facts: Appeal against conviction for indecent assault on minor under Section 145(1).
Assault.principle: Age of victim is critical element in sexual assault cases.

Assault.facts: Appeal against robbery conviction involving serious assault leaving victim maimed.
Assault.principle: Permanent injuries from assault aggravate robbery offenses.

Assault.facts: Assault case where victim escaped and hid during attack.
Assault.principle: Victim's escape narrative may corroborate assault allegations.

Assault.facts: Applicant was charged and convicted for assault contrary to Section 251 of the Penal Code.
Assault.principle: Conviction for assault requires proof of unlawful application of force under Section 251 of Penal Code.

Assault.facts: Civil suit seeking general damages against 1st defendant for assault.
Assault.principle: General damages are recoverable in civil cases for assault without need to prove special damages.

Assault.facts: Appeal against conviction where initial charge was assault but deceased died within one year of incident.
Assault.principle: Death within one year of assault may elevate charge from assault to more serious offence.

Assault.case_name: Neondo v Director of Public Prosecution
Assault.facts: Application challenging charge of assault causing actual bodily harm as second count.
Assault.principle: Multiple counts including assault must be properly framed to avoid duplicity.

Assault.facts: Land dispute where plaintiff was allegedly assaulted during confrontation.
Assault.principle: Assault occurring during land disputes may give rise to both civil and criminal liability.

Assault.facts: Criminal case where OB entry was produced to support assault claim against accused.
Assault.principle: Police OB entries can corroborate evidence in assault cases if properly produced.

Assault.facts: Accused claimed he didn't assault complainant despite evidence of unwarranted attack.
Assault.principle: Ownership disputes don't justify taking law into one's hands through assault.

Assault.case_name: Gitobu Imanyara & 2 others v Attorney General
Assault.facts: Appeal involving claims of torture, assault and malicious prosecution by police.
Assault.principle: State officers liable for assaults committed during unlawful arrests or detentions.

Assault.facts: Sentencing for accused with previous conviction for assault.
Assault.principle: Previous convictions for assault are aggravating factors in sentencing.

Assault.facts: Appeal against conviction where co-accused had injuries from assault.
Assault.principle: Physical injuries corroborate assault allegations against accused persons.

Fraud.case_name: A to Z Infrastructure Limited v Banking Fraud Investigation Unit & another
Fraud.facts: Challenge to Banking Fraud Investigation Unit's actions in Milimani Magistrate's Court case.
Fraud.principle: Banking fraud investigations must follow due process under criminal procedure laws.

Fraud.case_name: Mercy Nyawade v Banking Fraud Investigations Department & 2 others
Fraud.facts: Petition regarding closure of banking fraud investigation by DPP.
Fraud.principle: DPP has discretion to terminate banking fraud investigations.

Fraud.case_name: James Samuel Kinyanjui v Banking Fraud Investigation Department & 2 others
Fraud.facts: Challenge to banking fraud investigation procedures.
Fraud.principle: Banking fraud investigations require proper authorization and documentation.

Fraud.case_name: Brown Field Developers Limited v Banking Fraud Investigations Unit & 4 others
Fraud.facts: Petition challenging attempted fraud investigation by banking fraud unit.
Fraud.principle: Banking fraud investigations must be based on credible reports.

Fraud.case_name: Ogola Mujera Advocates LLP v Banking Fraud Investigation Unit & 2 others
Fraud.facts: Case involving Chase Bank investigation by banking fraud unit.
Fraud.principle: Law firms can challenge banking fraud investigations affecting clients.

Fraud.case_name: Republic v Sushila Arora & Another
Fraud.facts: Challenge to banking fraud department's handling of civil matters as criminal.
Fraud.principle: Banking fraud unit cannot criminalize civil disputes.
Fraud.agency: Kenya Police Banking Fraud Investigation Department

Fraud.case_name: Timothy Gachehe Kang'arua v Banking Fraud Investigation Unit
Fraud.facts: Case involving Equity Bank as interested party in fraud investigation.
Fraud.principle: Banks must cooperate with legitimate fraud investigations.

Fraud.case_name: Fructo Commodities Limited v Republic (BFIU & 2 others)
Fraud.facts: Criminal revision against banking fraud unit's investigation methods.
Fraud.principle: High Court can review banking fraud investigation procedures.

Fraud.case_name: Inland Africa Logistics Ltd v Republic (BFIU & 3 others)
Fraud.facts: Challenge to banking fraud unit's criminal investigation.
Fraud.principle: Companies can seek court intervention in banking fraud investigations.

Fraud.case_name: Republic v Chief Magistrate, Nairobi, Banking Fraud Investigating Unit, Attorney General & Director of Public Prosecutions; Mount Kenya University (Interested Party); Step Up Holding (K) Ltd (Exparte)
Fraud.facts: Judicial review application concerning banking fraud investigations and prosecutions.
Fraud.principle: Courts will scrutinize the legality of banking fraud investigations and prosecutorial decisions.

Fraud.case_name: Raphael Gervace Otieno Kopiyo & others v Inspector General of Police, Central Bank of Kenya Banking Fraud Investigation Department & Director of Public Prosecutions
Fraud.court: High Court (Anti-Corruption and Economic Crimes Division)
Fraud.facts: Petition challenging actions of Banking Fraud Investigation Department.
Fraud.principle: Banking fraud investigations must comply with constitutional safeguards and due process.

Fraud.case_name: Arthi Highway Developers Limited v West End Butchery Limited & 6 others
Fraud.facts: Case involving allegations of fraudulent transactions.
Fraud.principle: Fraud must be specifically pleaded and strictly proved in civil cases.

Fraud.case_name: Awino (Suing as Administratrix of Estate of Late Professor Fredrick Otieno) v Masinde Muliro University of Science & Technology & another
Fraud.facts: Dispute over employment contract allegedly obtained through fraud.
Fraud.principle: Fraud vitiates all contracts, including employment agreements.

Fraud.case_name: Pius Kipchirchir Kogo v Frank Kimeli Tenai
Fraud.facts: Land dispute involving allegations of fraudulent acquisition of title.
Fraud.principle: Fraud in land transactions defeats statutory protection of title.

Fraud.case_name: Gichinga Kibutha v Caroline Nduku
Fraud.facts: Case involving definition and proof of fraud in land transaction.
Fraud.principle: Fraud consists of deceitful acts intended to deprive another of their rights.

Fraud.case_name: Mungai & 13 others v Kabiru & 2 others
Fraud.facts: Land petition alleging fraudulent acquisition of title.
Fraud.principle: Fraudulently acquired titles are not protected by constitutional provisions.

Fraud.case_name: Joseph N.K. Arap Ng'ok v Moijo Ole Keiwua & 4 others
Fraud.facts: Land case examining when title can be challenged for fraud.
Fraud.principle: Registered title can only be challenged on grounds of fraud or misrepresentation.

Fraud.case_name: Kuria Kiarie & 2 others v Sammy Magera
Fraud.facts: Case involving both adverse possession and fraud claims.
Fraud.principle: Fraud claims must be specifically pleaded with particularity.

Fraud.case_name: Mrao Ltd v First American Bank of Kenya Ltd & 2 others
Fraud.facts: Banking case involving allegations of fraud in financial transactions.
Fraud.principle: Fraud in banking transactions vitiates contractual obligations.

Fraud.case_name: Damsyl Investment Limited v Director of Physical Planning & 8 others
Fraud.facts: Land dispute involving allegations of fraud in land subdivision process.
Fraud.principle: Fraud in land transactions must be specifically pleaded and strictly proved.

Fraud.case_name: Mwangale v Attorney General
Fraud.facts: Petition alleging fraud and coercion in land transfer transactions.
Fraud.principle: Fraud claims must be filed within 3 years of discovery under limitation laws.

Fraud.case_name: Elijah Makeri Nyangw'ra v Stephen Mungai Njuguna & another
Fraud.facts: Case involving forged documents used in land registration process.
Fraud.principle: Fraud vitiates all transactions; fraudulent titles must be cancelled.

Fraud.case_name: D.T Dobie & Company Ltd v Commissioner of Customs
Fraud.facts: Tax dispute involving allegations of fraudulent customs declarations.
Fraud.principle: Fraud allegations must be specifically pleaded and strictly proved in tax matters.

Fraud.case_name: Royalken Limited v China International Aero-Tech
Fraud.facts: Contract dispute with allegations of fraudulent inducement.
Fraud.principle: Contracts remain valid unless coercion, fraud or undue influence is proven.

Fraud.case_name: Alice Chemutai Too v Nickson Kipkurui Korir & 2 others
Fraud.facts: Land case involving allegedly fraudulently procured title deeds.
Fraud.principle: Fraudulent titles must be cancelled regardless of subsequent transfers.

Fraud.case_name: Katiti v Katiti
Fraud.facts: Appeal regarding land registration obtained through fraud.
Fraud.principle: Land register can be rectified for registrations obtained by fraud or mistake.

Fraud.case_name: Trust Bank Limited & Another v Investech Bank Ltd & 3 Others
Fraud.facts: Banking dispute with allegations of fraudulent transactions.
Fraud.principle: Fraud allegations in banking require concrete evidence, not mere suspicion.

Fraud.case_name: Philip Keipto Chemwolo & another v Augustine Kubende
Fraud.facts: Application to set aside default judgment based on alleged fraud.
Fraud.principle: Default judgments can be set aside for fraud, mistake or accident.

Fraud.case_name: Adnan & another v Mbae & 3 others
Fraud.facts: Case involving piercing corporate veil due to alleged fraudulent activities.
Fraud.principle: Corporate veil can be lifted only for proven fraud or criminal activities.

Bribery.case_name: Julius Lekakeny ole Sunkuli v Gideon Sitelu Konchellah & 2 others
Bribery.facts: Election petition involving allegations of bribery as an election offense.
Bribery.principle: Bribery is an election offense that requires strict proof.

Bribery.case_name: Nicholas Kiptoo Arap Korir Salat v Independent Electoral And Boundaries Commission & 7 others
Bribery.facts: Election petition alleging electoral malpractices including bribery.
Bribery.principle: Electoral malpractices including bribery must be specifically pleaded with particulars.

Bribery.case_name: Khatib Abdalla Mwashetani v Gideon Mwangangi Wambua & 3 others
Bribery.facts: Election appeal examining evidence required to prove bribery.
Bribery.principle: Courts will scrutinize evidence adduced to prove allegations of bribery in elections.

Bribery.case_name: Nicholas Kiptoo Arap Korir Salat v Independent Electoral & Boundaries Commission & 7 others
Bribery.facts: Election case discussing legal consequences of votes procured by bribery.
Bribery.principle: Votes procured through bribery may be invalidated under election laws.

Bribery.case_name: Nicholas Kiptoo Arap Korir Salat v Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission & 7 others
Bribery.facts: Appeal considering gravity of voter bribery allegations.
Bribery.principle: Courts must appreciate the serious nature of voter bribery allegations.

Bribery.case_name: Wetangula & another v Kombo & 5 others
Bribery.facts: Supreme Court case examining bribery as an election offense.
Bribery.principle: Bribery and treating are election offenses under statutory provisions.

Bribery.case_name: Republic v Henry Ngugi Njeru
Bribery.facts: Criminal case involving interpretation of the Bribery Act 2016.
Bribery.principle: The Bribery Act criminalizes both giving and receiving bribes.

Bribery.case_name: Republic v Juma Kalume Kalama
Bribery.facts: Case involving interpretation of provisions under the Bribery Act.
Bribery.principle: The Bribery Act repealed previous provisions on bribery offenses.

Bribery.case_name: Outa & another v Okello & 5 others
Bribery.facts: Supreme Court case on standard of proof for bribery allegations.
Bribery.principle: Allegations of bribery in elections require high and specific details.

Bribery.case_name: David Njilithia Mberia v Republic
Bribery.facts: Case involving application of the Bribery Act 2016.
Bribery.principle: The Bribery Act of 2016 provides the current legal framework for bribery offenses.

Bribery.case_name: Mberia v Republic
Bribery.court: High Court (Anti-Corruption and Economic Crimes Division)
Bribery.facts: Appeal involving interpretation of Section 18(8) of the Bribery Act.
Bribery.principle: The Bribery Act provisions must be strictly construed in corruption cases.

Bribery.case_name: AA Bayusuf & Sons Ltd & another v Northern Waterworks Development Agency & another
Bribery.facts: Commercial dispute where award was challenged on grounds including bribery.
Bribery.principle: Contracts or awards induced by bribery may be set aside by courts.

Bribery.case_name: Daniel Ongong'a Abwao v Mohamed Ali Mohamed & 2 others
Bribery.facts: Election petition examining what constitutes voter bribery.
Bribery.principle: Gifts to voters after casting ballots may not constitute bribery under election laws.

Bribery.case_name: Florence Wanjiku Muiruri v Republic
Bribery.facts: Appeal against conviction under Section 6(1)(a) of the Bribery Act.
Bribery.principle: The Bribery Act establishes specific penalties for bribery offenses.

Bribery.case_name: Arthur Kibira Apungu v Independent Electoral & Boundaries Commission & 2 others
Bribery.facts: Election case examining evidentiary requirements for proving voter bribery.
Bribery.principle: Voter bribery allegations require direct evidence linking accused to the offense.

Bribery.case_name: Shadrack Kirwa Tarus v Jackson Swadi Kedogo & another
Bribery.facts: Election petition with conflicting testimony about alleged bribery.
Bribery.principle: Bribery allegations in elections require credible witness testimony.

Bribery.case_name: Feisal Abdinoor Issack v IEBC & 2 others
Bribery.facts: Election petition treating voter bribery as criminal offense.
Bribery.principle: Voter bribery constitutes both an electoral offense and criminal violation.

Bribery.case_name: Osebe v Independent Electoral & Boundaries Commission & 2 others
Bribery.facts: Gubernatorial election petition involving bribery allegations.
Bribery.principle: Standard of proof for bribery in elections requires credible evidence.

Bribery.case_name: Omondi v Republic
Bribery.court: High Court (Anti-Corruption and Economic Crimes Division)
Bribery.facts: Appeal concerning application of Bribery Act to pending cases.
Bribery.principle: Transitional provisions of Bribery Act apply to pending bribery cases.

Bribery.case_name: Amitruck Limited v Blitz Logistics Limited
Bribery.facts: Arbitration case with allegations of award obtained through bribery.
Bribery.principle: Arbitral awards obtained through bribery may be challenged in court.

Bribery.case_name: Hosea Mundui Kiplagat v Sammy Komen Mwaita & 2 others
Bribery.facts: Election petition alleging widespread voter bribery.
Bribery.principle: Allegations of voter bribery must be specifically proved with concrete evidence.

Bribery.case_name: Philip Mukui Wasike v James Lusweti Mukwe, IEBC & Silas Rotich
Bribery.facts: Election petition examining standards for proving bribery allegations.
Bribery.principle: Bribery allegations must be supported by specific instances and evidence.

Bribery.case_name: Henry Ngugi Njeru v Republic
Bribery.facts: Case involving interpretation of Section 27(2) of the Bribery Act.
Bribery.principle: The Bribery Act contains transitional provisions for pending bribery cases.

Bribery.case_name: Martha Wangari Karua v Independent Electoral & Boundaries Commission & 3 others
Bribery.facts: Election appeal involving allegations of voter bribery.
Bribery.principle: Voter bribery constitutes an election offense under the Elections Offences Act.

Bribery.case_name: Karanja Kabage v Joseph Kiuna Kariambegu Nganga & others
Bribery.facts: Election petition with conflicting bribery allegations between candidates.
Bribery.principle: Unwitnessed bribery allegations may not meet the evidentiary threshold.

Bribery.case_name: Moses Masika Wetang'ula v Musikari Nazi Kombo & 2 others
Bribery.facts: Election appeal examining credibility of bribery allegations.
Bribery.principle: Direct denial of bribery allegations may defeat such claims if unsupported.

Bribery.case_name: Mercy Kirito Mutegi v Beatrice Nkatha Nyaga & 2 others
Bribery.facts: Election petition discussing pleading requirements for bribery claims.
Bribery.principle: Bribery allegations must be properly pleaded to form basis of challenge.

Bribery.case_name: Republic v Ethics and Anti Corruption Commission: Ex parte Margaret W. Mbote & 8 others
Bribery.facts: Judicial review concerning EACC's mandate under Bribery Act.
Bribery.principle: EACC is the statutory body mandated to enforce the Bribery Act.

Bribery.case_name: James Kiberenge Gatere & 3 others v IEBC & 2 others
Bribery.facts: Election case evaluating hearsay evidence of bribery.
Bribery.principle: Unreported and unwitnessed bribery allegations may constitute hearsay.

Bribery.case_name: Outa v Okello & 3 others
Bribery.facts: Supreme Court application challenging bribery allegations.
Bribery.principle: Bribery allegations must demonstrate complete evidentiary chain.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: The accused were prosecuted for offences under section 4(a) of the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act. The court acknowledged the seriousness of drug offences and their link to public harm.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Courts emphasize strict enforcement of narcotics laws to deter drug abuse and trafficking, recognizing the societal threat posed by drug-related offences.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.case_name: Musembi & 13 others v Moi Educational Centre Co. Ltd & 3 others
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: Petitioners argued that the operation of a school near a settlement with rising incidents of drug abuse, illicit brews, rape, and theft endangered children’s rights under the Constitution.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Constitutional protection of children requires proactive measures against environmental risks such as drug abuse and crime within proximity to learning institutions.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: The accused was convicted for drug trafficking. The court affirmed that the element of trafficking was adequately proved, especially its effect on societal safety and youth.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Successful prosecution for drug trafficking hinges on proving possession, knowledge, and intent to distribute narcotics, with courts reinforcing the social burden these crimes cause.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: The appellant was convicted of trafficking narcotic drugs. The judgment emphasized deterring misuse of motor vehicles in facilitating such crimes.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Where vehicles are used in the transportation of narcotics, courts may consider forfeiture and strict liability to prevent abuse of transport systems.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.case_name: Swabir Bukhet v Director of Public Prosecution
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: The petitioner challenged his charge for drug trafficking. The court reviewed rising public concerns over drug abuse and underscored the legal system's role in enforcement.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Kenyan courts consider the wider public interest in combating drug trafficking when interpreting the legality and procedure of arrests under the Narcotics Act.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.case_name: Director of Public Prosecution v Ibrahim Asala Mahangwa & 2 others
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: The respondents were accused of trafficking drugs concealed in a motor vehicle. Investigations focused on the 3rd respondent’s involvement and vehicle usage.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Concealment of drugs in transit vehicles is a common modus operandi in trafficking, and courts may draw inferences of intent from suspicious circumstances and evidence.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: The appellant faced counts of possession and trafficking of narcotic drugs. He contested both charges but was convicted.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Trafficking and possession are distinct offences under the Narcotics Act. Proof of either requires evidence of control, intent, and type of substance.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: The appellant was charged with trafficking narcotics. The judgment reflected on the broader harm drug misuse causes to society and affirmed the seriousness of the offence.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Trafficking offences are prosecuted rigorously given the state’s obligation to curb substance abuse and its consequences on youth and public health.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: The court evaluated whether the enforcement of a drug-related sentence was constitutional and discussed the statutory meaning of trafficking.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: The definition of trafficking under Kenyan law includes transporting, distributing, and possession with intent. Ambiguities in enforcement must be resolved in line with fair trial rights.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: The applicant challenged ongoing prosecution, arguing that it was an abuse of the court process. The court agreed, finding the application meritless and an abuse of the legal process.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: An application that lacks merit and is intended to obstruct justice constitutes abuse of court process and may be struck out.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.case_name: MOHAMED GHANI TAIB v REPUBLIC & IDRIS YUSUF BWANA v REPUBLIC
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: The appellants were charged with drug trafficking but claimed to be NGO workers fighting drug abuse. The court rejected this defense, finding evidence of actual trafficking activities.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Being affiliated with anti-drug organizations does not exempt one from criminal liability for actual participation in drug trafficking.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: The Assets Recovery Agency moved to freeze properties linked to drug proceeds. The respondent was already facing trafficking charges and his assets were considered proceeds of crime.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Drug trafficking is financially motivated, and proceeds linked to such crimes are subject to seizure under asset recovery laws.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: The accused were charged with trafficking 0.5 grams of narcotics. They argued the charge was disproportionate due to the small quantity involved.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Trafficking charges can be sustained regardless of the quantity involved, provided the intent to distribute is evident.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: The applicant contested his conviction for drug trafficking under section 4(a). The court upheld the conviction citing sufficient evidence and adherence to due process.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Drug trafficking convictions will stand where evidence is credible and procedural fairness is observed.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: The appellant challenged his conviction for narcotics trafficking. The court dismissed the appeal, stressing the harmful societal impact of drug offences.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Appellate courts uphold strong sentences for trafficking to deter drug abuse and protect society from its dangers.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: The applicant was found with 200g of narcotics. His case raised concerns about broader substance abuse and its influence on sentencing.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Sentences in drug offences may reflect not just quantity but also the surrounding context of abuse and repeat behavior.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.case_name: Bobby Macharia v Attorney General & 3 others
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: The petitioner faced multiple narcotic-related charges including aiding trafficking. Procedural issues in his arrest were raised but did not nullify the substantive offences.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Procedural irregularities do not exonerate an accused where substantive evidence of drug trafficking exists.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.case_name: Assets Recovery Agency v Wanjiru; Kimuri Housing Company Limited (Interested Party)
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: The respondent was found to be part of a complex network of narcotic drug traffickers and was convicted for drug trafficking. Asset recovery proceedings were instituted to seize properties obtained from proceeds of crime.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Conviction for drug trafficking may lead to civil asset forfeiture under anti-corruption and economic crimes laws.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.case_name: Noah Kipruto Kiplagat & another v Republic
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: One of the appellants was identified as a habitual drug user. The court considered his history with substance abuse in determining sentencing.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: A convict's background in substance abuse can influence the severity of sentencing for trafficking offences.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: The accused was linked to a drug trafficking ring moving substances between coastal towns. Surveillance and evidence confirmed involvement.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Geographical trafficking routes and coordinated operations are critical indicators in convicting traffickers.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: The court dismissed a revision application in a narcotics trafficking matter, terming it an abuse of process given pending proceedings elsewhere.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Frivolous applications intended to delay or disrupt drug trials constitute abuse of legal process.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: The appellant contested a trafficking conviction. The court upheld the conviction given the broad societal harm of drug offences.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: The social harm caused by drug trafficking justifies upholding strict legal standards and sentences.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: The appeal contested a trafficking sentence. The court emphasized the lasting harm drugs cause to youth and upheld the sentence.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Courts uphold trafficking penalties where societal impact—especially on youth—is evident.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: The agency moved to seize property linked to a convicted trafficker. The defence contested on technical grounds.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Civil recovery proceedings can follow criminal convictions for drug trafficking under anti-corruption law.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: One of the accused was charged with trafficking alongside charges of substance abuse. The court examined their joint roles.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Joint prosecution in trafficking and substance abuse charges requires distinct yet corroborative evidence for each count.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: Suspicion of trafficking arose from the appellant's possession of drugs valued using market estimates. She contested the valuation.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Market-based valuation of narcotics supports prosecutorial arguments on intent and severity in trafficking cases.

Drug Abuse and Trafficking.facts: The appeal was dismissed as the appellant failed to dispute core facts of the trafficking charge.
Drug Abuse and Trafficking.principle: Failure to dislodge the core elements of trafficking leads to affirmation of conviction.

Defilement.facts: Applicants were involved in a case citing group participation in the offence of rape or defilement under the Sexual Offences Act. The ruling emphasized joint intent and action.
Defilement.principle: Group commission of rape or defilement under the Sexual Offences Act constitutes aggravating circumstances.

Defilement.facts: Application raised issues of prolonged pre-trial detention in a defilement charge. Court reiterated that mandatory sentences for defilement are lawful.
Defilement.principle: Mandatory sentences for defilement are constitutionally valid and not excessive.

Defilement.facts: The appellant was charged with defilement. However, medical evidence did not support penetration, weakening the prosecution’s case.
Defilement.principle: Defilement requires medical and circumstantial evidence to prove penetration beyond reasonable doubt.

Defilement.facts: Applicant convicted of defiling an 11-year-old child and sentenced to life imprisonment.
Defilement.principle: Defilement of a child under 12 attracts a mandatory life sentence under the Sexual Offences Act.

Defilement.facts: The applicant challenged a conviction of attempted defilement, invoking Muruatetu principles.
Defilement.principle: Muruatetu guidelines on sentencing do not apply to defilement cases; statutory penalties prevail.

Defilement.facts: Conviction for defilement upheld; evidence established all necessary elements, including victim’s age and penetration.
Defilement.principle: Proof of age, penetration, and identity of offender are essential elements in defilement cases.

Defilement.facts: The appellant challenged the evidence presented in a defilement case involving a minor girl.
Defilement.principle: Emotional and psychological trauma of the victim considered in sentencing; credible testimony is key.

Defilement.facts: Medical evidence confirmed defilement. Appellant found in the act by a third party.
Defilement.principle: Direct eyewitness testimony combined with medical evidence secures a conviction for defilement.

Defilement.facts: Applicant charged under Section 8(1) of the Sexual Offences Act with defiling a child; application challenged procedure.
Defilement.principle: Section 8(1) of the Act criminalizes any penetration involving a child and prescribes mandatory punishment.

Defilement.facts: Appellant removed victim’s clothes and defiled her; victim later disclosed incident to a guardian.
Defilement.principle: Victim’s testimony supported by timely disclosure and corroborating evidence is admissible and sufficient.

Defilement.facts: The appellant was charged with defilement contrary to Section 8(1) and (4) of the Sexual Offences Act.
Defilement.principle: Defilement of a minor under Section 8 requires proof of sexual intercourse with a child below the prescribed age, even if consent is alleged.

Defilement.facts: Evidence of defilement was provided by a witness referred to as JM, indicating previous defilement the day before.
Defilement.principle: Corroborated evidence that defilement occurred on more than one occasion strengthens the prosecution's case.

Defilement.facts: The appellant was tried and convicted of defilement in the Chief Magistrates’ Court at Nanyuki under Section 8(1) of the Sexual Offences Act.
Defilement.principle: Conviction may be upheld when intercourse with a child below the specified age is proven, irrespective of the setting or consent.

Defilement.facts: Police officer Pc Kimichir recorded a defilement report; subsequent proceedings confirmed that the appellant did defile the complainant.
Defilement.principle: Proper documentation of defilement reports by police lends strong credibility, and judicial findings must align with recorded evidence.

Defilement.facts: After being taken into a forest, the complainant was defiled again; the court concluded that the child was indeed defiled.
Defilement.principle: Repeated defilement, especially with corroborated testimony, solidifies the legal finding of the offence.

Defilement.facts: The Court held that pregnancy is not a required element to prove defilement of a minor.
Defilement.principle: Defilement can be established without proof of pregnancy, emphasizing the child's sexual assault even without physical consequences.

Defilement.facts: The appellant grabbed the complainant, forced her to the ground, and defiled her; she later told him it had happened within her church community.
Defilement.principle: Force, coercion, or lack of consent, combined with the act of intercourse with a minor, satisfies the offence of defilement.

Defilement.facts: The appellant appealed against his conviction and sentence; the court noted that the minimum sentence for defilement is 15 years imprisonment.
Defilement.principle: Defilement offenses carry strict mandatory minimum sentences, reflecting the gravity of harming a child sexually.

Defilement.case_name: Neondo v Director of Public Prosecution
Defilement.facts: The appellant was convicted and sentenced to twelve years imprisonment for the offence of defilement under the Sexual Offences Act.
Defilement.principle: Sentencing in defilement cases must balance statutory minimums with circumstances of the offence and offender's profile.

Defilement.facts: Emmanuel Kipkoech was convicted and sentenced to 30 years imprisonment for defilement; the complainant was only 7 years old.
Defilement.principle: Courts apply increased sentences for defilement where the victim is a very young child, far below the age of consent.

Defilement.facts: The appellant had been convicted of defilement. The court affirmed the sentence as it fell within the statutory provisions under the Sexual Offences Act.
Defilement.principle: Defilement attracts mandatory sentencing under Section 8 of the Sexual Offences Act.

Defilement.facts: Appellant challenged the defilement conviction citing issues of identity and timing. Court ruled that the evidence proved he was the perpetrator.
Defilement.principle: Identity of the accused must be proven beyond reasonable doubt in defilement cases.

Defilement.facts: Applicant sought revision of sentence in a defilement conviction. Court declined noting seriousness of the offence and public interest.
Defilement.principle: Seriousness of defilement justifies full prosecution and sentence despite delays.

Defilement.case_name: Charles Owanga Aluoch v Director of Public Prosecutions
Defilement.facts: The appellant faced multiple allegations of defilement. Victim’s testimony lacked clarity and consistency in dates.
Defilement.principle: Precise particulars are crucial in defilement charges to uphold the right to fair trial.

Defilement.facts: The appellant was convicted of defilement based on medical and testimonial evidence confirming penetration.
Defilement.principle: Penetration is the key element in proving the offence of defilement under the Act.

Defilement.facts: Appellant was identified by the victim and found guilty of defilement. His appeal was dismissed due to consistent evidence.
Defilement.principle: Victim identification and testimony are sufficient where supported by medical findings.

Defilement.facts: The applicant was convicted of defilement and sought sentence revision. The court upheld the conviction and sentence.
Defilement.principle: Conviction for defilement under Section 8(1) of the Sexual Offences Act requires strict adherence to sentencing guidelines.

Defilement.facts: Appellant challenged a defilement conviction on grounds of improper charge framing. Court found that charge was properly stated and upheld the conviction.
Defilement.principle: Charges for defilement must clearly cite the relevant statutory provision and particulars.

Defilement.facts: Appellant had prior relations with victim; claimed consent. Court held that a child cannot legally consent to sex, thus convicting him.
Defilement.principle: Consent is irrelevant in cases of child defilement under Kenyan law.

Rape.facts: The appellant denied raping the complainant. The court held that rape can be proved through oral testimony of the victim or by circumstantial evidence.
Rape.principle: Rape may be established by the victim's uncontradicted oral evidence, even in absence of physical evidence, or through compelling circumstantial proof.

Rape.facts: Applicants were convicted of gang rape (Section 10 SOA) and sentenced to 15 years. The victim was 60 years old; sentencing reflected severity of offence.
Rape.principle: Under Section 10 of the Sexual Offences Act, gang rape—multiple perpetrators—is a distinct offence meriting enhanced punishment fitting both offence and victim’s vulnerability.

Rape.facts: The appellant was convicted of rape. The court affirmed that the trial magistrate properly understood the mens rea required for rape.
Rape.principle: Mens rea for rape requires intentional or reckless sexual intercourse without consent; courts must ensure proper understanding of this element.

Rape.facts: Court emphasized that the fact of rape can be proved by oral evidence of the victim or by circumstantial evidence.
Rape.principle: Courts are not compelled to rely on physical evidence alone; credible oral testimony of the complainant is sufficient to ground a rape conviction.

Rape.facts: Complainant’s credible testimony that two men assaulted and raped her in turns confirmed gang rape; State relied on Section 10 SOA and common intention.
Rape.principle: Gang rape convictions require proof of common intention among perpetrators; credible victim testimony is critical in establishing multiple assailants.

Rape.facts: Complainant testified about rape, was found to have torn clothes and broken hymen; court held oral evidence was sufficient even without medical report.
Rape.principle: Medical evidence corroborates but is not necessary when the complainant's oral testimony is credible and consistent.

Rape.facts: The complainant was taken into the forest and raped; court reiterated that oral testimony alone, if credible, suffices for rape conviction.
Rape.principle: Repetition of earlier principle—victim's credible evidence alone can ground rape convictions, even absent corroborating physical evidence.

Rape.case_name: Republic v Mwangi; ISLA & 3 others (Amicus Curiae)
Rape.facts: Case involved constitutional issues around definitions and sentencing for rape, defilement, and incest; court reviewed relevant maximum penalties and rights of complainants.
Rape.principle: Sexual offences are scrutinized under constitutional fairness; definitions and sentencing must uphold victim rights and proportional penalties.

Rape.facts: Applicants petitioned for comprehensive reforms in rape and sexual assault legislation, including improved medical services for victims.
Rape.principle: Court recognized need for legislative reform in handling sexual offences, particularly enhancing victim protection and support services.

Rape.facts: Applicant was charged with rape contrary to Section 3 of the Sexual Offences Act; judgment comments on legal standards required for proving rape.
Rape.principle: Rape under Section 3 demands proof of penetration without consent; courts affirm need for clear and convincing evidence.

Rape.facts: The court held that rape can be proven by oral evidence of the victim or circumstantial evidence, even without medical proof.
Rape.principle: Physical medical evidence is not mandatory where oral or circumstantial evidence proves rape.

Rape.facts: Case discussed statutory definitions of incest and rape, noting historical references to carnal knowledge and modern legal interpretations.
Rape.principle: The legal concepts of incest and rape rely on both statutory and contextual evidence of carnal knowledge within prohibited relationships.

Rape.facts: The court emphasized that rape requires proof of intention (mens rea), not merely a mental state of recklessness.
Rape.principle: Mens rea in rape cases must demonstrate deliberate intention to commit the act without consent.

Rape.facts: Initial charges were amended to rape following further investigation. The court confirmed rape based on medical and testimonial evidence.
Rape.principle: Charges may be amended to reflect factual developments; rape conviction requires corroborated victim testimony.

Rape.facts: The complainant was raped by multiple accused; the court accepted her consistent account of successive rapes as credible.
Rape.principle: Where multiple accused are involved, individual acts of rape must be considered distinctly and proved beyond doubt.

Rape.facts: The complainant testified that Dan and another person raped her; the court found the narrative credible and consistent.
Rape.principle: Joint acts of rape must still satisfy individual thresholds of criminal liability; victim’s testimony is pivotal.

Rape.facts: The complainant suspected rape; the court emphasized that intent to rape must be clearly established for conviction.
Rape.principle: Suspicion of rape is insufficient—there must be concrete proof of both actus reus and mens rea.

Rape.case_name: Isaac Nyoro Kimita & another v Republic
Rape.facts: Successive acts of rape by multiple men were evaluated; court ruled each should be charged separately.
Rape.principle: Each act of rape by different individuals must be treated as a separate count, even if arising from one incident.

Rape.facts: Court stated that where consent is proven, rape cannot stand. The presence of consent negates the charge.
Rape.principle: Proof of consent nullifies the essential element of rape under Section 140 of the Penal Code.

Rape.facts: Court examined whether the evidence supported attempted rape and assault; found insufficient basis for rape conviction.
Rape.principle: Attempted rape requires clear intention and overt act; lack of evidence defeats the charge.

Rape.facts: The appellant challenged his rape conviction. The court held that for rape to be established, there must be clear evidence of intent to rape.
Rape.principle: Rape requires manifest intention to commit the act and lack of consent.

Rape.case_name: Charles Owanga Aluoch v Director of Public Prosecutions
Rape.facts: Inconsistencies in the complainant’s statements cast doubt on the allegation of rape. The case emphasized the need for consistent testimony.
Rape.principle: Consistency in victim testimony is critical to uphold rape charges.

Rape.facts: The appellant was convicted of rape. The court affirmed that lack of consent is the essential element in proving rape.
Rape.principle: Rape is defined by lack of consent, not just the act of penetration.

Rape.facts: The court considered whether the accused killed in furtherance of a felony—rape. The presence of rape as an underlying felony enhanced the charge to murder.
Rape.principle: Killing in the course of rape constitutes felony murder under Kenyan law.

Rape.facts: The charge was changed mid-trial from rape to attempted rape. The appellant had admitted elements of the offence.
Rape.principle: Charge substitution must reflect the facts admitted or proven; attempted rape requires intention.

Rape.facts: The evidence presented confirmed that the victim was raped. The conviction was upheld on the strength of victim testimony and proximity.
Rape.principle: Rape can be proven through corroborated victim testimony and circumstantial evidence.

Rape.facts: Victim was raped by two men, but the charge filed was not gang rape. The court noted the discrepancy and emphasized correct charge framing.
Rape.principle: Group sexual assault must be charged as gang rape under Section 10 of the Sexual Offences Act.

Rape.facts: The court reiterated that the lack of consent is the foundation of a rape charge and the mens rea must reflect intent.
Rape.principle: Mens rea for rape is based on intent, and lack of consent must be clearly established.

Rape.facts: The court found that fondling did not amount to rape or attempted rape, due to lack of violence or penetration.
Rape.principle: Rape or attempted rape must involve violence and penetration or a clear attempt.

Rape.facts: The court found that the accused had manifest intention to rape and upheld the conviction based on circumstantial and medical evidence.
Rape.principle: Intent to rape must be clearly demonstrated through actions or threats accompanying the act.

Manslaughter.facts: The appellant pleaded guilty to a reduced charge of manslaughter. He appealed the sentence imposed after the plea.
Manslaughter.principle: A plea of guilty to manslaughter must be unequivocal and sentencing must consider mitigating factors.

Manslaughter.facts: The accused were not charged with murder but manslaughter. The court noted the absence of intent to kill.
Manslaughter.principle: Manslaughter is a cognate and lesser offence where malice aforethought is absent.

Manslaughter.facts: Court reduced the charge from murder to manslaughter based on evidence lacking intent to kill.
Manslaughter.principle: Charge of murder may be reduced to manslaughter if malice aforethought is not proven.

Manslaughter.facts: State proposed reduction of murder to manslaughter. The accused declined to plead guilty to the lesser charge.
Manslaughter.principle: A charge reduction requires acceptance by the accused; plea must be voluntary and informed.

Manslaughter.facts: Appellant was convicted of manslaughter. Evidence did not support the element of malice aforethought required for murder.
Manslaughter.principle: When evidence negates intent to kill, conviction should be for manslaughter, not murder.

Manslaughter.facts: Appellant convicted of manslaughter and sentenced to five years imprisonment.
Manslaughter.principle: Sentencing in manslaughter should consider circumstances, including remorse and provocation.

Manslaughter.facts: Accused pleaded guilty to manslaughter under a plea agreement. The court emphasized the seriousness of the felony.
Manslaughter.principle: Manslaughter, though a lesser charge than murder, is a grave felony punishable by life imprisonment.

Manslaughter.facts: The accused pleaded guilty to manslaughter and was convicted accordingly.
Manslaughter.principle: Voluntary plea to a lesser offence of manslaughter is acceptable where supported by facts.

Manslaughter.facts: Following discussions between prosecution and defense, the murder charge was reduced to manslaughter under Section 205 of the Penal Code.
Manslaughter.principle: Plea bargaining may result in reduction of murder to manslaughter where appropriate.

Manslaughter.facts: The court convicted the accused of manslaughter following a plea agreement concluded a day prior.
Manslaughter.principle: Plea agreements in manslaughter cases must be guided by law and accepted by court before sentencing.

Manslaughter.facts: The killing of the deceased was determined to amount only to manslaughter, not murder.
Manslaughter.principle: Where the circumstances lack malice aforethought, a conviction for manslaughter is substituted for murder.

Manslaughter.facts: Charges were ordered against police officers for either murder or manslaughter in connection with a death.
Manslaughter.principle: Charges must reflect evidence of either murder or manslaughter depending on facts, particularly concerning state actors.

Manslaughter.facts: Conviction on manslaughter was entered pursuant to a plea bargain agreement reducing the original charge.
Manslaughter.principle: Plea bargain agreements can lawfully reduce charges from murder to manslaughter with court approval.

Manslaughter.facts: Suspects arrested and arraigned to answer charges for either murder or manslaughter, emphasizing due process.
Manslaughter.principle: Proper criminal procedure mandates arraignment on appropriate charges aligned with evidence.

Manslaughter.case_name: Bonaya Tutu Ipu & another v Republic
Manslaughter.facts: Court noted the maximum sentence for manslaughter is life imprisonment under the relevant section.
Manslaughter.principle: Manslaughter carries a maximum penalty of life imprisonment, differing from murder’s harsher sentencing.

Manslaughter.facts: Trial judge explained differences between murder and manslaughter; conviction was substituted to manslaughter.
