Manslaughter.principle: Distinction between murder and manslaughter hinges on presence or absence of malice aforethought.

Manslaughter.facts: Charge of murder substituted with manslaughter due to lack of proof of malice aforethought.
Manslaughter.principle: Absence of malice aforethought requires conviction for manslaughter rather than murder.

Manslaughter.facts: Petitioner convicted and sentenced to 20 years imprisonment for manslaughter.
Manslaughter.principle: Manslaughter convictions attract substantial custodial sentences though less than murder.

Manslaughter.facts: Without malice aforethought, the court would have convicted the accused of manslaughter.
Manslaughter.principle: Malice aforethought is crucial for murder; absence results in manslaughter convictions.

Manslaughter.facts: Intoxication considered in reducing conviction from murder to manslaughter.
Manslaughter.principle: Intoxication may diminish culpability, warranting conviction on lesser charge of manslaughter.
If ‘malice aforethought’ is lacking, the unlawful homicide will be manslaughter.
Where ‘malice aforethought’ is lacking, the unlawful homicide will be manslaughter; issues of provocation may affect the verdict.

Manslaughter.facts: Assessors found the accused guilty of manslaughter.
Manslaughter.principle: Assessment of guilt can lead to manslaughter conviction based on evidence.
Without malice aforethought, a conviction for manslaughter applies; intoxication evidence may reduce the charge.

Manslaughter.facts: Charge reduced from murder to manslaughter upon plea agreement.
Manslaughter.principle: Plea agreements may reduce murder charges to manslaughter; manslaughter attracts life imprisonment.
Conviction for murder substituted with manslaughter where facts support lesser offence.
Manslaughter offence elements defined; accused found guilty contrary to section 202 of Penal Code.

Manslaughter.facts: Convicted of manslaughter after full trial; liable to imprisonment for life under section 202.
Manslaughter.principle: Felony of manslaughter attracts life imprisonment.

Manslaughter.facts: Pleaded guilty and convicted of manslaughter.
Charge reduced to manslaughter; sentence is life imprisonment.

Terrorism.case_name: Muslim Human Rights Forum & Another v Commandant of the Anti-Terrorism Police Unit & 2 Others
Terrorism.facts: Applicants challenged actions by the Anti-Terrorism Police Unit, raising constitutional and human rights concerns.
Terrorism.principle: The court scrutinized powers of anti-terrorism authorities against fundamental human rights.

Terrorism.case_name: ASA & 4 others v Noorani; Anti-Terrorism Police Unit & another (Interested Parties)
Terrorism.facts: Petitioners challenged actions by the Anti-Terrorism Police Unit raising constitutional issues related to counter-terrorism.
Terrorism.principle: Court emphasized constitutional limits and rights safeguards in anti-terrorism enforcement.

Terrorism.case_name: Legal Advice Centre t/a Kituo Cha Sheria & 33 others v Cabinet Secretary, Ministry of Education & 7 others
Terrorism.facts: Litigants, including victims of Garissa University attack, challenged government’s response and policies on terrorism and education.
Terrorism.principle: State counter-terrorism measures must comply with constitutional protections and human rights obligations.

Terrorism.case_name: Kenya Human Rights Commission v Nubian Rights Forum & others
Terrorism.facts: A multi-party suit involving human rights organizations and government agencies addressing counter-terrorism policies.
Terrorism.principle: Balancing national security and fundamental freedoms in enforcement of counter-terrorism laws.

Terrorism.case_name: Nubian Rights Forum, Kenya Human Rights Commission & Kenya National Commission on Human Rights v Attorney-General & others
Terrorism.facts: Petitioners challenged government institutions on constitutional and human rights grounds related to national security policies.
Terrorism.principle: Court emphasized government accountability and human rights compliance in security operations.

Terrorism.case_name: Ahamad Abolfathi Mohammed & another v Republic
Terrorism.facts: Appeal involved accused persons arrested by Anti-Terrorism Police Unit with allegations of terrorism-related offences.
Terrorism.principle: The court examined evidentiary standards and procedural safeguards in terrorism prosecutions.

Terrorism.facts: The accused was alleged to have planned activities related to terrorism; prosecution failed to establish connection.
Terrorism.principle: Prosecution must present concrete evidence to link accused to terrorism activities for conviction.

Terrorism.case_name: Ali v Director of Public Prosecutions & another
Terrorism.facts: Case related to ongoing terrorism trials; discussed the scope and application of the Prevention of Terrorism Act, 2012.
Terrorism.principle: The Prevention of Terrorism Act defines specified terrorism offences and governs trial procedures.

Terrorism.case_name: Pioneer Holdings (Africa) Limited v Concord Insurance Company Limited & another
Terrorism.facts: Dispute over applicability of terrorism exclusion clause in insurance policies.
Terrorism.principle: Terrorism exclusion clauses in insurance contracts must be strictly interpreted.

Terrorism.case_name: Ahamad Abolfathi Mohammed & another v Republic
Terrorism.facts: Appeal on anti-terrorism charges involving Anti-Terrorism Police Unit procedures and evidence admissibility.
Terrorism.principle: Court emphasized rights of accused and strict scrutiny of evidence in terrorism cases.

Terrorism.facts: The appellant was accused of undergoing military-style training in Somalia, a country officially designated as a terrorism training ground. The prosecution relied on Section 30C of the Prevention of Terrorism Act, which presumes guilt under certain circumstances related to terrorism training. The case highlights the government's efforts to curb terrorism through prosecuting individuals linked to foreign terror groups.
Terrorism.principle: Presumption of guilt under anti-terrorism law where training in designated terror regions is proven.

Terrorism.facts: The accused was charged under Section 2 of the Prevention of Terrorism Act, with prosecution relying heavily on evidence of involvement in terror-related activities. Section 30 of the Act was pivotal, detailing the elements of the terrorism offence. The case focused on the sufficiency of evidence linking the accused to terrorist conduct.
Terrorism.principle: Definition and application of terrorism offences under the Prevention of Terrorism Act.

Terrorism.case_name: Sophia Juma Swaleh v Inspector General of Police & 3 others
Terrorism.facts: Petitioner challenged actions linked to the terrorist group Al Shabaab, alleging unlawful arrest and human rights violations. The petition involved issues around counter-terrorism enforcement and the legality of police actions against suspected terror operatives.
Terrorism.principle: Human rights protection versus security operations in the fight against Al Shabaab.

Terrorism.facts: The accused was linked to videos and audio materials propagating terrorism messages. The case centered on the definition of a terrorist group under the Prevention of Terrorism Act and the use of digital media as evidence of terrorist affiliations.
Terrorism.principle: Use of multimedia evidence to establish terrorism links and prosecution of related offences.

Terrorism.facts: Accused charged with multiple counts related to terrorism, including membership of a terrorist organization. The case underscored Kenya’s ongoing struggle with terrorism and the broad scope of anti-terror laws used to prosecute individuals.
Terrorism.principle: Scope of charges under terrorism laws and Kenya’s national security context.

Terrorism.facts: The accused was charged with membership in a terrorist gang under Section 24 of the Prevention of Terrorism Act 2012. The case addressed procedural issues in terrorism prosecutions and the standards required for conviction under the Act.
Terrorism.principle: Legal thresholds for proving membership of terrorist groups.

Terrorism.facts: The court considered Section 35 of the Prevention of Terrorism Act relating to terrorism offences, evaluating evidence and interpreting statutory provisions for convicting accused persons.
Terrorism.principle: Interpretation of terrorism offence provisions and evidentiary requirements.

Terrorism.facts: The accused disseminated audio messages encouraging recruitment to Al-Shabaab. The court examined how propaganda materials are used to support terrorist recruitment and the implications for criminal liability.
Terrorism.principle: Criminal liability for dissemination of terrorist propaganda.

Terrorism.case_name: Muslims for Human Rights (Muhuri) & another v Inspector-General of Police & 4 others
Terrorism.facts: The petitioners challenged counter-terrorism actions by police authorities, seeking clarity on the definition and scope of terrorism under Kenyan law. The court’s decision clarified the legal framework and standards for counter-terrorism enforcement.
Terrorism.principle: Legal definition of terrorism and limits of state action in counter-terrorism.

Terrorism.facts: The accused was charged under sections 30B and 30C of the Prevention of Terrorism Act related to training or instructions for terrorist purposes. The court analyzed the sufficiency of evidence linking the accused to terrorist training.
Terrorism.principle: Evidence standards for terrorism training offences under the Prevention of Terrorism Act.

Terrorism.facts: The accused were charged with unlawful killing but the court found there was no evidence of malice aforethought necessary for murder. The killing was instead classified as manslaughter, recognizing the absence of intent to kill but holding the accused responsible for the unlawful death.
Terrorism.principle: If ‘malice aforethought’ is lacking, the unlawful homicide will be manslaughter.

Terrorism.facts: The accused was charged with murder following a killing, but the court found insufficient proof of malice aforethought. Consideration was given to provocation and circumstances that negated intent. Consequently, the conviction was for manslaughter, reflecting that while the accused caused death unlawfully, there was no premeditation or intent to kill.
Terrorism.principle: Where ‘malice aforethought’ is lacking, the unlawful homicide will be manslaughter; issues of provocation may affect the verdict.

Terrorism.facts: The accused was tried for killing but the assessors found the evidence insufficient for murder and recommended a conviction for manslaughter. The court upheld this, emphasizing that manslaughter applies where death results from unlawful acts without intent to kill or where intent is not proven beyond reasonable doubt.
Terrorism.principle: Assessment of guilt can lead to manslaughter conviction based on evidence.

Terrorism.facts: The accused appealed a murder conviction, arguing that intoxication affected his mental capacity at the time of the killing. The court considered that the evidence supported a conviction for manslaughter instead, due to lack of intent. This case highlights how intoxication may reduce the charge where it negates malice aforethought.
Terrorism.principle: Without malice aforethought, a conviction for manslaughter applies; intoxication evidence may reduce the charge.

Terrorism.facts: The accused originally faced a murder charge but, under a plea bargain, the charge was reduced to manslaughter. The court accepted the agreement, recognizing that the facts and evidence supported a lesser offence and noting that manslaughter carries a maximum penalty of life imprisonment.
Terrorism.principle: Plea agreements may reduce murder charges to manslaughter; manslaughter attracts life imprisonment.

Terrorism.facts: The appellant was initially convicted of murder, but the appellate court found the facts supported only manslaughter. The conviction was substituted accordingly, emphasizing the importance of correctly assessing intent and circumstances surrounding the unlawful killing.
Terrorism.principle: Conviction for murder substituted with manslaughter where facts support lesser offence.

Terrorism.facts: The accused was charged with manslaughter under section 202 of the Penal Code following an unlawful killing. The evidence showed that although death was caused unlawfully, the required intent for murder was absent. The accused was convicted accordingly.
Terrorism.principle: Manslaughter offence elements defined; accused found guilty contrary to section 202 of Penal Code.

Terrorism.facts: After a full trial, the accused was convicted of manslaughter due to lack of evidence showing malice aforethought. The court sentenced the accused to life imprisonment under section 202 of the Penal Code.
Terrorism.principle: Felony of manslaughter attracts life imprisonment.

Terrorism.facts: The accused pleaded guilty to manslaughter following an incident where the victim died unlawfully but without intent to kill. The plea was accepted, and the accused was convicted accordingly.

The accused’s murder charge was reduced to manslaughter. The court found the evidence did not support intent to kill but confirmed unlawful killing. The accused was sentenced to life imprisonment for manslaughter.

Forgery.case_name: Karanja v Director of Public Prosecution & another
Forgery.facts: The petitioner challenged the actions of law enforcement and prosecutors who investigated and intended to charge him with forgery. Allegations were made that he had engaged in forgery, and there was concern raised about potential abuse of court process if the forgery allegations were unfounded. The case underscores the importance of safeguarding individuals from wrongful prosecution where evidence is insufficient.
Forgery.principle: Protection against abuse of court process and requirements for establishing prima facie forgery.

Forgery.case_name: D.T Dobie & Company Ltd v Commissioner of Customs and Border Control
Forgery.facts: The respondent alleged forgery related to customs documentation. Given the seriousness of forgery and fraud allegations, the Tribunal emphasized the high evidentiary standard needed to prove forgery. This case highlights the intersection of forgery allegations with tax and customs enforcement.
Forgery.principle: High evidentiary standard required for proving forgery in customs-related disputes.

Forgery.case_name: Damsyl Investment Limited v Director of Physical Planning, Ministry of Lands, Planning and Housing & 8 others
Forgery.facts: The dispute involved allegations that a mutation form used for subdivision of land was forged. The plaintiff was tasked with proving the forgery allegations, which centered on authenticity and signatures on critical land transaction documents. The case emphasizes how forgery issues critically impact land rights and property transactions.
Forgery.principle: Burden of proof in forgery claims affecting land registration and title documents.

Forgery.case_name: In re Edith Wanjiku Gitao (Deceased)
Forgery.facts: The case involved confirmation of Grant of Letters of Administration which was challenged on grounds of forgery. The court examined compelling evidence presented to substantiate allegations that critical documents related to estate administration were forged, raising issues on the integrity of succession processes.
Forgery.principle: Requirement for compelling evidence to prove forgery in succession and estate administration cases.

Forgery.case_name: Republic v Director of Public Prosecutions & 3 others; Otumba (Exparte Applicant); Rono & another
Forgery.facts: The court underscored the need to protect the criminal justice system’s integrity from abuse, specifically when forgery allegations are involved. The judgment analyzed the elements and legal definitions of forgery, including conspiracy and obtaining goods by false pretenses, emphasizing the need for credible evidence to convict.
Forgery.principle: Guarding the justice system from abuse through strict requirements on evidence in forgery cases.

Forgery.case_name: Republic v Barno & 5 others; Sayan Investments Limited (Victim)
Forgery.facts: The accused were charged with forgery contrary to Sections 347(A) and 349 of the Penal Code. The case involved detailed scrutiny of forged documents and their impact on commercial interests of the victim company, highlighting how forgery offences affect business operations.
Forgery.principle: Application of Penal Code provisions on forgery and protecting commercial interests.

Forgery.case_name: Kamichar & 7 others v Delmonte Kenya Limited; Directorate of Criminal Services & 2 others
Forgery.facts: This case involved allegations that a mention notice and signature purportedly belonging to the defendant were forged. The court examined the authenticity of documents central to ongoing litigation, illustrating how forgery allegations can complicate civil and criminal proceedings.
Forgery.principle: Role of document authenticity in litigation and implications of forged court process documents.

Forgery.case_name: Arthi Highway Developers Limited v West End Butchery Limited & 6 others
Forgery.facts: The court found that multiple documents relied upon by the appellant were forgeries, concluding these forged documents did not bind the opposing party. This case reinforces that forged documents carry no legal weight and cannot be used to bind parties in contractual disputes.
Forgery.principle: Legal ineffectiveness of forged documents in contractual obligations.

Forgery.case_name: Nduru v Avenue Service Station Ltd
Forgery.facts: Respondent’s counsel alleged that a contract presented by the claimant was forged. The court noted that forgery is a serious allegation and must be supported by clear evidence, especially in employment disputes where contractual authenticity is contested.
Forgery.principle: Requirement of clear proof to substantiate forgery allegations in employment contracts.

Forgery.case_name: Kaigi General Contractors Limited v National Irrigation Authority
Forgery.facts: The defendant failed to report forgery allegations to police or any authority, which the court noted in assessing the credibility of claims related to document forgery. This case underlines the importance of timely reporting and investigation of forgery allegations in contractual disputes.
Forgery.principle: Impact of failure to report forgery allegations on credibility in contractual disputes.

Forgery.case_name: James Kanyiita Nderitu & another v Marios Philotas Ghikas & another
Forgery.facts: The appellants challenged orders issued by Mbito, J., which they claimed were forged. The first affidavit disowned these orders as forgeries, raising serious questions about the authenticity of the documents used in the proceedings. The Court of Appeal examined whether the alleged forgeries undermined the legal process.

Forgery.case_name: REPUBLIC v COMMISSIONER OF POLICE & another EX-PARTE MICHAEL MONARI & another
Forgery.facts: The case concerned allegations of forgery and obtaining property by false pretences. The criminal proceedings aimed at proving the forgery allegations, emphasizing the need to establish the falsification of documents beyond reasonable doubt in criminal law.

Forgery.case_name: Kasuki t/a Glory Secondary School & 2 others v County Government of Kajiado & 2 others
Forgery.facts: The respondents faced serious accusations of forgery or fraud in relation to land documents. The court stressed the high standard of proof required when such grave allegations are made, given their potential impact on property rights and transactions.

Forgery.case_name: APEC Holdings Limited v Kenya Railways Corporation
Forgery.facts: This dispute involved the legality of a land acquisition process where the plaintiff alleged that the documents presented by the defendant were forged. The court examined documentary evidence and raised questions about the authenticity of the exhibits relied upon by the parties.

Forgery.case_name: Jennifer Nyambura Kamau v Humphrey Mbaka Nandi
Forgery.facts: The appellant argued that the trial court erred by failing to explicitly determine whether forgery had been proven regarding a transfer form used in the proceedings. The court reviewed whether the evidence supported the allegation of forgery and how the failure to address this issue affected the judgment.

Forgery.case_name: Wafula (Derivatively on behalf of) Transnzoia Investment Company v Walubengo & 6 others
Forgery.facts: The court found that key exhibits presented by the 6th and 7th defendants were forgeries, undermining their claims. The judgment underscored the critical impact forged documents have on litigation, particularly concerning property disputes.

Forgery.case_name: Lotukumo v Burudi & 2 others
Forgery.facts: In a land dispute, the first defendant failed to specifically plead fraud or forgery despite challenges raised by the plaintiffs. The court considered the implications of absent pleadings on the ability to prove forgery allegations.

Forgery.case_name: Kwamboka v Symbio Healthcare Limited
Forgery.facts: The respondent relied on a conflicting employment contract and alleged forgery as a defense. The court reviewed the occurrence book report alleging forgery and discussed the absence of statutory time limits for prosecuting criminal offenses such as forgery in an employment context.

Forgery.case_name: Mohamed Abdi Mahamud v Ahmed Abdullahi Mohamad & 3 others
Forgery.facts: This case related to an election petition where allegations of criminal forgery and fraud were raised. The court clarified that the petition concerned the qualification of candidates and was not an inquiry into criminal forgery, emphasizing the separation of election matters from criminal investigations.

Forgery.case_name: Urmila w/o Mahendra Shah v Barclays Bank International Ltd & another
Forgery.facts: The appellant claimed the cheque in question was a forgery; however, there was no previous claim or evidence to support the allegation. The court found that the cheque was not proven to be a forgery, affirming the importance of concrete proof when alleging forgery.

Forgery.case_name: Mbuthia Macharia v Annah Mutua Ndwiga & another
Forgery.facts: The appellant was charged with forgery linked to sworn statements allegedly made between parties. The first respondent was convicted of forgery, highlighting the court’s examination of evidentiary authenticity in disputes involving sworn declarations.
Forgery.principle: Authenticity of sworn statements and its role in forgery charges.

Forgery.case_name: Kenneth Nyaga Mwige v Austin Kiguta & 2 others
Forgery.facts: The appellant did not contest or allege forgery of the document marked for identification during trial. This case underscores that failure to dispute the authenticity of documents can lead to their admissibility and weight as evidence.
Forgery.principle: Importance of timely contesting document authenticity in forgery allegations.

Forgery.case_name: Kabutiyei v Ketbonet Bookstores Limited
Forgery.facts: The respondent alleged that a key letter submitted was forged, raising issues around the authenticity of documentary evidence in land-related disputes. The court considered the seriousness of the forgery claim in evaluating the land transaction evidence.
Forgery.principle: Handling of forgery allegations in land court documentary evidence.

Forgery.case_name: Kuria Kiarie & 2 others v Sammy Magera
Forgery.facts: The respondent alleged that a will presented was forged. The court noted that serious allegations like forgery or fraud require a high evidentiary standard before acceptance, especially when inheritance and property rights are at stake.
Forgery.principle: High evidentiary standards for forgery allegations in will and probate matters.

Forgery.case_name: Paan v Kariuki & 16 others
Forgery.facts: Although forgery was suspected in property documents, the complainant did not report the alleged forgery to authorities but lodged a complaint elsewhere. This highlights issues of delayed reporting and its impact on credibility in forgery allegations.
Forgery.principle: Effect of failure to promptly report forgery on case credibility.

Forgery.case_name: Kasturi Limited v Nyeri Wholesalers Limited
Forgery.facts: The appellant claimed that two lease agreements in possession of the respondents were forged. The court examined the validity of multiple leases to determine their binding nature, emphasizing the legal consequences of forged contractual documents.
Forgery.principle: Legal invalidity of forged lease agreements and their effect on possession claims.

Forgery.case_name: In re Estate of Julius Mimano (Deceased)
Forgery.facts: Forgery allegations were raised regarding documents related to the deceased’s estate; however, no evidence was led to substantiate the forgery claims. This highlights the court's requirement for concrete proof in forgery accusations.
Forgery.principle: Necessity of evidence to support forgery allegations in estate matters.

Forgery.case_name: Kimuri Housing Company Limited v GC Retail Limited & 3 others
Forgery.facts: A document examiner’s report was crucial in confirming that signatures on Indentures were forged. The court referenced previous cases to highlight the legal consequences of fraud and forgery in land transactions.
Forgery.principle: Use of expert evidence in proving forgery of signatures on land documents.

Forgery.case_name: Anyange v Republic
Forgery.facts: The case involved a series of burglaries accompanied by fraud and associated forgeries of property documents. It reflects the broader use of forgery in facilitating criminal activities beyond civil disputes.
Forgery.principle: Forgery as an instrument in criminal conspiracies involving property theft.

Forgery.case_name: In Re Estate of Solomon Ngatia Kariuki (Deceased)
Forgery.facts: An objection based on alleged forgery was raised, but the objector conceded to never reporting the forgery to police. The case illustrates the importance of official reporting to bolster forgery claims.
Forgery.principle: Role of formal police reporting in substantiating forgery allegations.

Abortion.case_name: Federation of Women Lawyers (Fida – Kenya) & 3 others v Attorney General & 2 others; East Africa Center for Law & Justice & 6 others (Interested Party) & Women’s Link Worldwide & 2 others (Amicus Curiae)
Abortion.facts: This constitutional petition highlighted the high induced abortion rate in Kenya—48 abortions per 1,000 women—and challenged the legal restrictions impeding access to safe abortion and post-abortion care services. The case advocated for protection of women’s reproductive rights within the legal framework.
Abortion.principle: Recognition of safe abortion access as a critical public health and human rights issue.

Abortion.case_name: PAK & another v Attorney General & 3 others
Abortion.facts: The court affirmed that access to safe abortion services is a fundamental human right. The judgment tackled the gap between legal provisions and practical access, emphasizing the importance of safe, legal reproductive health services to protect women’s lives.
Abortion.principle: Access to safe abortion as a human right under Kenyan law.

Abortion.facts: The case discussed spontaneous abortion and referenced the advent of medical abortion methods. It contextualized how advancements in medical science have influenced judicial understanding of abortion-related cases.
Abortion.principle: Judicial recognition of medical abortion as an alternative method influencing case facts.

Abortion.facts: Evidence included a father’s admission that his child’s pregnancy was aborted due to serious illness. This case showed the intersection of personal circumstances and the sensitive nature of abortion evidence in criminal trials.
Abortion.principle: Impact of medical and personal facts on abortion-related prosecutions.

Abortion.case_name: Dr Lucas Ndungu Munyua v Royal Media Services Limited & another
Abortion.facts: The plaintiff acknowledged that abortion is a criminal offence punishable by imprisonment but argued that abortion is also a matter of public interest. The case highlights the tension between criminal law and public discourse on abortion.
Abortion.principle: Balancing criminal sanctions against public interest in abortion debates.

Abortion.case_name: Attorney General & 3 others v PAK & another
Abortion.facts: The respondent was charged with procuring abortion contrary to Kenyan law. The court dealt with the legal ambiguity surrounding abortion and the ongoing debate on whether abortion is illegal or permitted under certain circumstances.
Abortion.principle: Judicial consideration of the legality and boundaries of abortion offences.

Abortion.facts: The pathologist's evidence ruled out abortion in a death case. The judgment clarifies evidential standards regarding the cause of death in suspected abortion-related cases.
Abortion.principle: Forensic evidence in distinguishing abortion-related deaths.

Abortion.facts: Medical examination found that the deceased had attempted to procure an abortion and suffered post-abortion infection, which was a key factor in the criminal proceedings.
Abortion.principle: Medical evidence as central in abortion offence prosecutions.

Abortion.facts: The medical report indicated an incomplete abortion, highlighting medical complications relevant to the court's assessment of the case facts.
Abortion.principle: Role of medical reports in abortion-related criminal trials.

Abortion.facts: The accused was not charged specifically with abortion, though the medical test indicated a complete abortion. The case highlights complexities in charge framing in abortion-related matters.

The prosecution failed to call crucial witnesses, particularly the medical practitioner who conducted the abortion, raising issues about the completeness of the evidence. The absence of the doctor’s testimony weakened the prosecution's case regarding the circumstances of the abortion.

The complainant informed authorities that the appellant had impregnated her and facilitated an abortion. The evidence included testimonies about the aborted pregnancy and medical complications resulting from the procedure, which were central to the criminal proceedings.

Evidence showed that the complainant had been pregnant and had taken abortifacient drugs. The case examined the circumstances under which the abortion was procured and its legality, including medical and testimonial evidence.

The appellant was accused of facilitating abortion without medical supervision. Tablets provided were used by the complainant to abort a foetus. The court noted the prosecution failed to call the medical doctor who allegedly carried out the abortion, impacting the strength of the prosecution's evidence.

The complainant had undergone an incomplete abortion, requiring medical attention. The appellant contested some elements of the prosecution, but medical evidence indicated the complainant was admitted to hospital with complications from an incomplete abortion.

Medical testimony revealed that the complainant had undergone an incomplete abortion, which had failed to fully terminate the pregnancy. The court reviewed the evidence related to medical complications and the appellant’s role in the abortion.

There was clear medical evidence of an abortion with features consistent with an incomplete abortion. The case focused on establishing the facts surrounding the abortion and the accused’s involvement.

The accused argued the abortion allegedly procured in June 2017 was substantiated by medical evidence, including the presence of an aborted foetus. The case involved evaluating the credibility of the evidence surrounding the abortion.

The accused decided to assist another individual in procuring an abortion. Testimony from the defense noted that the complainant had two abortions, complicating the factual matrix and influencing the court’s assessment of the accused's involvement.

Medical testimony from PW2 admitted that the deceased was prescribed drugs to prevent abortion but nonetheless managed to abort the foetus. The case dealt with medical evidence concerning the circumstances and legality of the abortion.

facts: The complainant underwent a medical abortion procedure performed by a doctor which failed to terminate the pregnancy.
After the failed abortion attempt, the complainant carried the pregnancy to term and eventually gave birth.
The case highlights the challenges and legal considerations surrounding failed abortion attempts.
The appellant was accused of requesting the complainant to procure an abortion.
Evidence showed that abortion drugs were obtained from a known source (Kazungu) for the purpose of inducing abortion.
The case underlines the illegal procurement and distribution of abortion-inducing drugs.

Abortion.case_name: Jeremiah Wanyiri Wambugu v Geofrey Wiagwa Wanjoya
facts: This case dealt with whether a contract of sale was 'aborted' or terminated prematurely.
The facts clarify the legal distinction between abortion in contract law and medical abortion.
Although the term 'aborted' appears, this case is unrelated to the criminal offence of abortion.
The appellant denied allegations of procuring abortion during police interrogation.
An investigation led by Officer Joshua Kwale was conducted to verify the abortion report.
The case exemplifies procedural and investigative steps in abortion allegations.
The accused provided abortion pills to the complainant, attempting to procure an abortion.
Although the abortion attempt caused heavy bleeding, the baby survived.
This case illustrates the consequences and criminal liability when abortion attempts harm the fetus but do not succeed.
Medical evidence including an ultrasound (PEXH.4) confirmed that the complainant had undergone an abortion.
The case stresses the role of medical and forensic evidence in establishing abortion offences.
The prosecution failed to demonstrate how the abortion was induced or connect the accused directly to the act.
It remained speculative whether the accused was responsible for the abortion.
This case underscores the need for clear and direct evidence in abortion prosecutions.
The accused was charged with causing the successful abortion of a conceived fetus.
He claimed ignorance about the medicine used to procure the abortion.
The case highlights issues of knowledge and intent in abortion-related criminal liability.
The complainant kept money received and did not attempt or procure an abortion.
The case clarifies legal distinction between an attempt and actual abortion.
The accused confirmed that a wire could be used to procure abortion.
He was charged with attempting, not completing, the procurement of an abortion.
This highlights the criminal liability attached to attempts to procure abortion even if unsuccessful.

The absence of the doctor’s testimony weakened the prosecution's case regarding the circumstances of the abortion.

Evidence showed that the complainant had been pregnant and had taken abortifacient drugs. The case examined the circumstances under which the abortion was procured and its legality, including medical and testimonial evidence.

The appellant was accused of facilitating abortion without medical supervision. Tablets provided were used by the complainant to abort a foetus. The court noted the prosecution failed to call the medical doctor who allegedly carried out the abortion, impacting the strength of the prosecution's evidence.

The complainant had undergone an incomplete abortion, requiring medical attention. The appellant contested some elements of the prosecution, but medical evidence indicated the complainant was admitted to hospital with complications from an incomplete abortion.

Medical testimony revealed that the complainant had undergone an incomplete abortion, which had failed to fully terminate the pregnancy. The court reviewed the evidence related to medical complications and the appellant’s role in the abortion.

There was clear medical evidence of an abortion with features consistent with an incomplete abortion. The case focused on establishing the facts surrounding the abortion and the accused’s involvement.

The accused argued the abortion allegedly procured in June 2017 was substantiated by medical evidence, including the presence of an aborted foetus. The case involved evaluating the credibility of the evidence surrounding the abortion.

Corruption.case_name: Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission (The legal successor of Kenya Anti - Corruption Commission) v Stanley Mombo Amuti
facts: The case involved allegations of corrupt conduct defined broadly as conduct constituting corruption or economic crime.
It emphasized Kenya's constitutional and international obligations to outlaw corruption and implement anti-corruption conventions.

Corruption.case_name: Republic v Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission & 2 others
facts: The case dealt with procedural and jurisdictional issues involving the Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission.
It referenced a related precedent involving Christopher Ndarathi Murungaru, highlighting challenges in prosecuting corruption cases.

Corruption.case_name: Senior Principal Magistrates’ Court, MSA (Sitting as the Anti-corruption court) v The Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission
facts: The prosecution informed the Anti-Corruption court about investigations and charges involving corruption offences.
The ruling clarified the role and powers of the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission in criminal investigations.

Corruption.case_name: Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission successor of Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission v Midland Finance & Securities Limited & 2 others
facts: This civil appeal involved the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission acting as a successor to Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission.
The case addressed financial irregularities and corruption allegations involving Midland Finance and other entities.

Corruption.case_name: Stanley Mombo Amuti v Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission
facts: The appellant challenged corruption-related charges, discussing the scourge of money laundering and economic crimes in Kenya.
The court examined evidentiary standards and procedural fairness in anti-corruption prosecutions.

Corruption.case_name: Pravin Bowry v Ethics & Anti-Corruption Commission
facts: The claimant contested employment-related decisions made by the Ethics & Anti-Corruption Commission.
The case considered procedural fairness and administrative law principles in actions taken by the Commission.

Corruption.case_name: Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission v Vibco Limited
facts: The case concerned allegations of corrupt conduct by Vibco Limited.
The court interpreted the legal definitions of 'corrupt conduct' under relevant anti-corruption legislation.

Corruption.case_name: Ethics & Anti Corruption Commission v Moses Kasaine Lenolkulal
facts: The case involved investigation and prosecution related to alleged corruption activities.
It reaffirmed the mandate of the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission to investigate and prosecute corruption-related offences.

Corruption.case_name: Ethics & Anti-Corruption Commission v Njuguna Macharia
facts: The plaintiff relied on precedents including Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission cases to establish claims related to corruption.
The case illustrated the Commission's involvement in land and environmental corruption disputes.

Corruption.case_name: Ethics and Anti Corruption Commission v Jamal Bare Mohamed
facts: The Commission investigated corruption and economic crime allegations involving the respondent.
The ruling discussed the investigative powers of the Commission and the evidentiary thresholds for prosecution.

Corruption.case_name: BERYL AKINYI MUGANDA v ETHICS & ANTI CORRUPTION COMMISSION
Corruption.facts: The applicant challenged actions taken by the Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission, seeking to set aside certain orders. The case centered on procedural and substantive legality of the Commission’s measures aimed at tackling corruption, highlighting the role of the Commission in enforcing anti-corruption laws.

Corruption.case_name: Ethics & Anti-Corruption Commission v Katangi Distributors Limited
Corruption.facts: The Ethics & Anti-Corruption Commission brought an application against Katangi Distributors Limited alleging involvement in corrupt practices. The case examined the Commission’s authority under the Ethics & Anti-corruption Commission Act and the applicability of anti-corruption provisions to corporate entities in relation to land and environmental matters.

Corruption.case_name: Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission v Omar Sheriff Mohammed
Corruption.facts: The case dealt with allegations of corruption and economic crimes related to land transactions. The court considered evidence submitted by the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission and the legal thresholds for establishing corrupt conduct under the Anti-Corruption and Economic Crimes Act.

Corruption.case_name: KENYA ANTI-CORRUPTION COMMISSION v CELERON BUSINESS SYSTEMS
Corruption.facts: The Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission sought orders under section 56 of the Anti-Corruption and Economic Crimes Act against Celeron Business Systems. The case focused on the Commission’s power to investigate and prosecute alleged corrupt practices involving corporate entities, setting important precedents on the enforcement powers of the Commission.

Corruption.case_name: KENYA ANTI-CORRUPTION COMMISSION v STANLEY MOMBO AMUTI
Corruption.facts: The appeal involved allegations of corrupt conduct by Stanley Mombo Amuti. The court analyzed the interpretation of 'corrupt conduct' within the context of the Anti-Corruption and Economic Crimes Act, clarifying legal principles related to evidence and mens rea in corruption cases.

Corruption.case_name: KENYA ANTI-CORRUPTION COMMISSION v STANLEY MOMBO AMUTI
Corruption.facts: This High Court case involved an application under the Anti-Corruption and Economic Crimes Act, focusing on charges against Stanley Mombo Amuti. The proceedings examined the evidence of corrupt conduct and the statutory powers of the Anti-Corruption Commission in pursuing economic crimes.

Corruption.case_name: Hasan Mohamed v Ethics and Anti Corruption Commission & another
Corruption.facts: Hasan Mohamed challenged actions taken by the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission. The case involved judicial review of the Commission’s procedures and compliance with constitutional safeguards during investigations of corruption allegations.

Corruption.case_name: KENYA ANTI-CORRUPTION COMMISSION v CELERON BUSINESS SYSTEMS
Corruption.facts: In a related proceeding to the earlier Celeron Business Systems case, the Commission sought orders to further investigate alleged corrupt transactions. This case reinforced the powers of the Commission under section 56 of the Anti-Corruption and Economic Crimes Act.

Corruption.case_name: KENYA ANTI-CORRUPTION COMMISSION v KOWICH PHILIP ONYANGO
Corruption.facts: This case involved an application under the Anti-Corruption and Economic Crimes Act. The Commission sought to exercise its investigative powers against Kowich Philip Onyango for alleged corrupt conduct involving economic crimes.

Corruption.case_name: KENYA ANTI-CORRUPTION COMMISSION v GIGIRI COURT LIMITED
Corruption.facts: The Commission alleged that Nairobi Block 91/386 was acquired through corrupt conduct. The case focused on proving the illicit origin of property and the Commission’s mandate to recover assets obtained through corruption.

Corruption.case_name: Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission v Stanely Mombo Amuti
facts: The case was heard in the Anti-Corruption and Economic Crimes Division of the High Court Nairobi.
Involved investigation and prosecution of economic crimes and corruption allegations against Stanley Mombo Amuti.
Focused on procedural adherence under the Anti-Corruption and Economic Crimes Act.

Corruption.case_name: Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission v Jamal Bare Mohamed
facts: Prosecution under the Anti-Corruption and Economic Crimes Act No. 3 of 2003.
Allegations involved economic crimes with the EACC acting as the prosecuting authority.
The case focused on the sufficiency of evidence to prove corruption-related offenses.

Corruption.case_name: Pravin Bowry v Ethics & Anti-Corruption Commission
facts: Petition challenging certain provisions of the Anti-Corruption and Economic Crimes Act.
The petitioner sought declarations against EACC actions, including constitutionality of Section 61A of the Act.
Examined issues of administrative fairness and due process in EACC operations.

Corruption.case_name: Stanley Mombo Amuti v Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission
facts: The appellant challenged the actions of the Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission regarding corruption investigations.
Case emphasized the powers and jurisdiction of KACC in combating corruption under the Anti-Corruption and Economic Crimes Act.

Corruption.case_name: Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission v Thinga Developers Limited
facts: Case concerned allegations of corrupt conduct involving Thinga Developers Limited.
Referred to precedent involving Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission v Vibco Limited on the definition and scope of corrupt conduct.

Corruption.case_name: Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission v Moses Kasaine Lenolkulal
facts: Case involved charges of corruption-related offences brought by EACC.
Court considered evidence and legal standards under the Anti-Corruption and Economic Crimes Act.

Corruption.case_name: County Government Of Meru v Ethics And Anti-Corruption Commission
facts: The petition challenged investigations conducted by the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission into alleged corruption within the County Government of Meru.
Raised questions on the scope of EACC’s investigative powers under the Anti-Corruption and Economic Crimes Act.

Corruption.case_name: Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission v Stanley Mombo Amuti
facts: Reiteration of the term 'corrupt conduct' and its application in prosecutions under the Anti-Corruption and Economic Crimes Act.
Detailed legal analysis of charges brought against Stanley Mombo Amuti.

Corruption.case_name: Ethics & Anti Corruption Commission (EACC) v Lydia Ngini Lentinina
facts: Case involved investigation under the United Nations Convention Against Corruption (UNCAC).
EACC had reasonable suspicion that funds involved were proceeds of corruption.
Focused on asset recovery and tracing corruptly obtained money.

Corruption.case_name: Ethics & Anti-Corruption Commission v Sachdeva Nabhan & another
facts: Case under the Anti-Corruption and Economic Crimes Act No. 3 of 2003.
The Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission prosecuted allegations of economic crimes involving the respondents.
Ruling discussed evidentiary requirements and procedural compliance.
The petitioner was accused of unlawfully committing bigamy by marrying another woman while still married.
The respondent lodged a police complaint in 2010 alleging the petitioner had committed bigamy.

Bigamy.case_name: G M v D M M
facts: The marriage was annulled on grounds of bigamy.
The appellant was found incompetent to marry due to an existing subsisting marriage, constituting the felony of bigamy.
The accused person was charged with the offence of bigamy under criminal law.

Bigamy.case_name: R S B v S K
facts: The respondent was found guilty of cruelty, desertion, and bigamy.
The accused was charged with bigamy for marrying without the consent of the spouse.

Bigamy.case_name: P W v G M S
facts: The applicant caused the respondent to be charged with the offence of bigamy.
Criminal procedural ruling where the accused was charged with the offence of bigamy.
Customary law case noting bigamy as an offence under the Penal Code.
The accused was a competent witness for the prosecution in a case where the offence was bigamy.
The case discussed the offence of bigamy.

Bigamy.facts: The accused was charged with bigamy, a criminal offence involving contracting a second marriage while the first subsists. The court clarified that this was not a case of bigamy or sexual offence but focused on the specific elements of bigamy offences under Kenyan law, examining the marital status and legal implications of the accused's relationships.

Bigamy.case_name: S A G v B N O
Bigamy.facts: The respondent was accused of committing adultery and bigamy following marriage. Evidence showed the respondent was cohabiting with another person in a relationship akin to marriage, raising issues about the validity of marriages and whether the second relationship constituted bigamy under the law.

The accused was charged with bigamy. The court examined procedural issues including the competency of witnesses in bigamy cases, specifically whether a spouse could testify against the accused. The case highlighted legal nuances in prosecuting bigamy under the Penal Code.

The appellant was convicted of bigamy, having contracted two marriages simultaneously. The court underscored the gravity of bigamy as a felony under Kenyan law, emphasizing the importance of compliance with marital laws prohibiting multiple concurrent marriages.

This succession case dealt with the validity of the deceased’s marriage, which was declared unlawful and void on the basis that it was a product of bigamy, a criminal offence. The court considered the implications of the criminal nature of bigamy on inheritance and estate distribution rights.

Bigamy.case_name: In re Estate Of: The Estate Of Giovanni Gremmo (Deceased)
Bigamy.facts: The court dealt with succession issues arising from bigamy. Testimony indicated that a monogamous marriage violated by subsequent marriages could lead to prosecution for bigamy. The ruling considered the legal consequences of such relationships on estate claims.

The appellant challenged a bigamy conviction, prompting the court to discuss evidential requirements and procedural rules applicable in bigamy prosecutions. The ruling emphasized the need for the prosecution to establish the subsistence of the first marriage at the time of the second marriage.

The petitioner filed for divorce on grounds of bigamy, alleging the respondent was married to another person at the time of their marriage. The case highlighted how bigamy serves as grounds for dissolution of marriage under family law.
The accused was charged with bigamy. The court considered the elements of the offence and the legal framework governing the prosecution and defense of bigamy charges.

Bigamy.case_name: Director of Public Prosecutions v Maero
Bigamy.facts: This consolidated ruling discussed evidential standards in prosecuting bigamy, focusing on admissibility of evidence and procedural fairness. The court elaborated on statutory protections afforded to accused persons and the burden of proof required to establish bigamy.

facts: The plaintiff sought a suit and prayed that the respondent be charged with the offence of bigamy.

Bigamy.case_name: Teresiah Syombua Mutuku v Idah Nduku Masyuki
facts: The deceased purported to conduct another marriage with the appellant, leading to an allegation of bigamy.

Bigamy.case_name: M M v J K M
facts: The applicant was found to have committed the offence of bigamy by marrying another person after leaving the first spouse.

Bigamy.case_name: H N N v M N & Another
facts: The 1st respondent was alleged to be planning a criminal offence of bigamy by entering into another marriage while subsisting marriage existed.
The case involved declaration of property rights from cohabitation founded on the crime of bigamy.
The accused was charged with the offence of bigamy.
The offence of bigamy was defined under section 171 of the Penal Code, and the accused was liable for marrying more than permitted by law.
It was held that a spouse is competent to testify in a criminal trial if the charge involves bigamy.

Bigamy.case_name: Lucy Mwendwa Muuru v Tony Githuku
facts: The presumption of marriage could not be allowed where it would amount to permitting bigamy, referencing case law from Whiston (1998).
The accused was charged with the offence of bigamy.

Elopement.facts: The complainant allegedly eloped with the appellant on 30th January 2010, proceeding to his rural home. The defense raised questions on the plausibility of the elopement date, challenging the prosecution's timeline.
The complainant reported eloping from home with the appellant. The case examined the circumstances under which the complainant left her home and the nature of the relationship with the appellant.

Elopement.case_name: Abdirahman Mohamed Abdi & Another v Adan Yussuf
Elopement.facts: The respondent claimed that the second appellant's partner was pregnant with his child at the time she eloped. However, evidence indicated the woman eloped with the first appellant following a divorce and without pregnancy.

The prosecution witness (PW1) testified to having eloped with the appellant after being discovered by her brother. PW1 gave a detailed account of how the appellant enticed her to elope with him, highlighting issues of consent and coercion.

The appellant, who was HIV positive, was noted to have taken advantage of a vulnerable young girl who was sent home from school due to unpaid fees. The girl eloped with the appellant under these circumstances.

The complainant’s family only became aware of an affair after the girl eloped with the accused. The accused deliberately chose to elope with a school-going minor, raising issues of statutory protection.
The complainant, aged 15 years, eloped with the appellant in October 2014 after they became friends. The court reviewed the age and voluntariness in the context of the elopement.
This case concerned a clear instance of elopement where the appellant took the complainant away on 20th September 2020 without parental consent, raising criminal and procedural issues.
The complainant’s father suspected that she had eloped with the appellant. Evidence was led to establish whether the elopement was consensual and known to the appellant beforehand.
The complainant’s mother testified that the complainant eloped and went to live with her husband, which raised issues related to the legality and consent in the elopement.

facts: PW5 testified during cross-examination that when the appellant eloped with the girl, it appeared both had the intention to elope.
The appellant admitted to eloping with the complainant.
The court found that penetration had occurred and noted the complainant freely chose to elope.
The appellant testified he received a report indicating the complainant had eloped.
PW1 eloped twice with the appellant; first returning home but later eloping again.
The appellant offered and facilitated elopement with the complainant, using it as a cover for previous mistakes.

Elopement.case_name: D O O v G A O
facts: The respondent eloped with J O, escaping to Nyanza Province.
The respondent was found to have committed desertion by eloping with another man.
PW7 testified that a person named D sent her brother who had eloped with the complainant.
The court found no reason to doubt this evidence.
After discovering the minor was pregnant, the parties decided to elope.
The complainant was rescued separately from the appellant where he was arrested.
A tip-off indicated the appellant was planning to elope with the complainant.
On the day the complainant eloped with him, her mother informed authorities.
The appellant and complainant had schemed for a while to elope at an opportune moment.
The court found it inconceivable that the appellant could have eloped with her on the stated date as alleged.

Elopement.facts: The appellant allegedly eloped with the complainant who was a standard pupil. The prosecution case was that the appellant eloped with the complainant leading to the alleged offence.
principles: Elopement can be a key fact in determining consent and age-related issues in sexual offences.
The status of the complainant as a minor intensifies the legal scrutiny of the relationship.

Elopement.facts: The complainant testified she was seduced by the appellant at school, and they eloped. The evidence portrayed them as young lovers who eloped.
principles: Elopement may indicate consensual relationship but does not necessarily negate statutory offences.
Age and consent remain critical in sexual offence prosecutions involving minors.

Elopement.facts: The complainant informed the appellant she was pregnant. The appellant accepted and agreed to elope with her on 29th December 2018.
principles: Elopement post-pregnancy acknowledgment may affect credibility and motive analysis.
Such agreements between parties do not absolve legal responsibility if statutory offences are involved.

Elopement.facts: The complainant became pregnant and eloped with the appellant at his request. Cohabitation was corroborated by witness evidence.
principles: Cohabitation following elopement is often scrutinized to establish relationship nature and consent.
Pregnancy is a significant factor in cases involving elopement and sexual offences.

Elopement.facts: The complainant, in Standard 4, disappeared from school after allegedly eloping with the accused.
principles: Elopement of minors from school triggers investigation of statutory rape or abduction.
The age of the complainant is pivotal in establishing the offence.

Elopement.facts: The accused eloped with the complainant after his release from custody.
principles: Elopement post-release may indicate ongoing relationship relevant to offence analysis.
Voluntary cohabitation can be evidence of consent but must be examined in light of statutory protections.

Elopement.facts: The appellant made advances culminating in the complainant's elopement. Prosecution witnesses identified him as the person involved.
principles: Persistent advances followed by elopement may be used to establish intent and culpability.
Witness testimony can be pivotal in proving identity and sequence of events.

Elopement.facts: The matter was initially treated as a case of elopement, with suspicion that J eloped with the accused.
principles: Initial assumptions of elopement require corroboration before forming basis of prosecution.
Differentiating between consensual elopement and criminal abduction is essential.

Elopement.case_name: H K M v D M A
Elopement.facts: The appellant averred that she and the respondent eloped and cohabited.
principles: Joint admission of elopement and cohabitation impacts credibility and legal status of the relationship.
Cohabitation may affect claims in matrimonial and criminal proceedings.

Elopement.facts: The victim provided overwhelming evidence she had eloped with the appellant and cohabited for close to a week.
principles: Duration and nature of cohabitation post-elopement informs assessment of consent and relationship dynamics.
Victim testimony is critical in establishing facts around elopement and subsequent events.

Child to child sex.facts: The Court clarified that in sexual offences, the slightest penetration of a female sex organ by a male sex organ is sufficient to constitute the offence.
legal_principles: Minimal penetration suffices to establish the offence of sexual penetration.
Consent and penetration are key elements in sexual offence prosecution.

Child to child sex.facts: The appellant was charged with defilement of a child after demanding sex as payment for services rendered to the victim, MA, a minor.
legal_principles: Demanding sex as consideration for services to a child constitutes exploitation and defilement.
Protection of minors from sexual exploitation is paramount in criminal law.

Child to child sex.facts: The complainant testified that the appellant forced her to have sex against her will but did not inform anyone afterwards.
legal_principles: Non-consensual sex constitutes an offence regardless of whether the victim reports immediately.
The silence of a victim post-offence does not negate the offence.

Child to child sex.facts: The court reiterated that the slightest penetration suffices for defilement under sexual offence laws.
legal_principles: The law does not require proof of complete penetration, only slightest penetration.
Legal standards on penetration in defilement cases are minimal and protective.

Child to child sex.facts: The complainant revealed prior consensual sex with the appellant. There were contradictory testimonies regarding habitual sexual relations.
legal_principles: Prior sexual history may be considered but does not automatically imply consent in subsequent acts.

Child to child sex.case_name: Republic v Mwangi; Initiative for Strategic Litigation in Africa (ISLA) & 3 others (Amicus Curiae)
Child to child sex.facts: The court considered proposals for adopting age gap provisions to address consensual sex issues, including age brackets for consensual relations.
legal_principles: Age gap provisions can provide legal clarity on consensual sex between minors and adults.

Child to child sex.facts: The complainant had consensual sex with the appellant and made him her boyfriend; court considered age of consent laws from England for comparison.
legal_principles: Consent must be legally valid based on age restrictions.

Child to child sex.facts: During voir dire, the complainant testified the appellant had sexual intercourse with her multiple times, establishing a pattern.
legal_principles: Repeated acts of sexual penetration can strengthen the prosecution's case.

Child to child sex.facts: The complainant, who was pregnant, testified she had engaged in sexual relations with the appellant; age and consent were discussed.
legal_principles: Pregnancy can be corroborative evidence of sexual activity.
Age of complainant impacts the evaluation of consent and offence.

Child to child sex.facts: The complainant testified that she had unprotected sex with the appellant on two occasions, resulting in pregnancy.
legal_principles: Unprotected sex resulting in pregnancy is strong evidence in sexual offence cases.
Repeated sexual acts strengthen the prosecution's factual matrix.

facts: The appellant entered the complainant’s bedroom through the window on three different nights and had sexual intercourse.
The court confirmed penetration by the male organ is sufficient to constitute the offence.

Child to child sex.case_name: AOO & 6 others v Attorney General & another
facts: The case involved constitutional issues regarding sex and age.
The ruling touched on protection of minors from sexual offences.
For purposes of sexual offences, a child below 18 years cannot consent to sex.
The court treated the child complainant as incapable of consenting.
The appellant caused his penis to penetrate the vagina of a child (S W).
The complainant admitted to having engaged in sex, but the law still considers it an offence given the age.
The court held that any act with a child under the age of consent constitutes an offence of indecent act with a child.

Child to child sex.case_name: Mary Rono v Jane Rono & another
facts: The case involved a 20-year-old unmarried woman with no child at the time.
The facts centered around issues related to sex.
The child narrated the sexual offence to PW2.
The accused claimed impotence and stated he did not engage in sexual acts.

The accused admitted the complainant pushed him away and stopped the act before it went too far.

The court referenced minimum sentencing aimed at addressing societal problems related to sexual offences.

Child to child sex.case_name: Micheni Aphaxard Nyaga & 2 others v Robert Njue & 2 others
facts: The case dealt with issues of discrimination based on gender and sex in inheritance.
The court stated categorically that discrimination in inheritance on the basis of gender or sex is impermissible.

Treason.facts: Application concerning death penalty for capital offenses including treason.
Treason.Legal_Principle: Treason remains among the capital offenses subject to death penalty under Kenyan law.

Treason.case_name: Muruatetu & another v Republic; Katiba Institute & 4 others (Amicus Curiae)
Treason.facts: Landmark case giving directions on mandatory death sentence, including for treason.
Treason.Legal_Principle: Supreme Court directions on death penalty apply to treason cases alongside murder.

Treason.facts: Application concerning criminal case involving treason charges.
Treason.Legal_Principle: Treason charges carry significant legal consequences and procedural requirements.

Treason.Legal_Principle: Treason is among offenses where bail considerations are particularly strict.

Treason.Legal_Principle: High Court has exclusive jurisdiction over treason cases.

Treason.facts: Application concerning capital offenses including treason.

Treason.facts: Case concerning jurisdiction over serious offenses.

Treason.Legal_Principle: Conviction for treason carries mandatory death sentence under Kenyan law.

Treason.case_name: Pkosing v National Super Alliance & 12 others
Treason.facts: Election petition examining whether boycott constituted treason.
Treason.Legal_Principle: Political boycotts may potentially be construed as treason under certain circumstances.

Treason.case_name: REPUBLIC v MOSES KENU OLE PEMBA
Treason.facts: Under Section 72(5) of the repealed Constitution, no person accused of murder or treason is allowed bail; courts are prohibited from granting bond/bail in such offences.
Legal_Principle: Section 72(5) prohibits bail for accused persons charged with murder or treason.
Courts lack discretion to grant bail in such cases.

Treason.facts: The court held that the restriction on bail under the repealed Constitution applied to capital offences beyond murder, such as treason, affirming the mandatory death sentence for these offences.
Legal_Principle: Mandatory death sentence applies to capital offences including treason.
Bail restrictions for murder extend similarly to other capital offences.

Treason.facts: The accused was charged with murder under Sections 203 and 204 of the Penal Code as well as treason, highlighting serious criminal allegations requiring strict procedural adherence.
Legal_Principle: Murder and treason charges attract serious legal consequences and procedural rigor.
Penal Code Sections 203 and 204 outline the legal framework for murder offences.

Treason.case_name: REPUBLIC v JOHN KAHINDI KARISA & 2 others
Treason.facts: Application of Section 123 of the Criminal Procedure Code which classifies offences such as murder and treason with respect to bail and trial procedures.
Legal_Principle: Section 123 Criminal Procedure Code governs procedural aspects for murder and treason offences.
Certain offences are treated as capital, affecting bail and trial rights.

Treason.facts: Addressed issues of treason accusations based on trivial incidents; reflected concerns about misuse of treason charges for political or other purposes.
Legal_Principle: Treason accusations require substantive evidence, not trivial grounds.

Treason.facts: Confirmed that murder, treason, and robbery with violence (committed or attempted) are offences covered under Section 123 of the Criminal Procedure Code with stringent bail restrictions.
Legal_Principle: Strict bail conditions apply to murder, treason, and violent robbery offences.
Section 123 Criminal Procedure Code restricts bail for serious offences.

Treason.case_name: Republic v Erick Masega Alias Madiaba

Legal_Principle: Legal framework mandates strict handling of serious offences like murder and treason.

Treason.facts: Echoed earlier jurisprudence affirming that offences like murder and treason invoke mandatory restrictions on bail and specific trial requirements.

Treason.case_name: Charles Henry Nyaoke v Cabinet Secretary, Ministry of Interior and Co-ordination of National Government & 4 others
Treason.facts: Confirmed that trials for murder and treason must follow constitutional and procedural safeguards, with implications on bail and trial conduct.
Legal_Principle: Trial of capital offences must adhere to constitutional safeguards.

Treason.facts: The accused was charged with murder, a capital offence. Legal_Principle: Capital offences attract mandatory death penalty or severe sentencing.

The case explored the legal definition of treason, evidentiary requirements, and procedural safeguards for accused persons in capital offence trials, highlighting the seriousness of such charges.
Legal_Principle: Treason is a capital offence that requires high evidentiary standards.
Due process must be strictly observed in capital offence trials to safeguard rights.

The court reaffirmed that murder, treason, and robbery with violence attract mandatory sentences and clarified that judicial discretion cannot override these mandates.
Legal_Principle: Mandatory sentences apply to capital offences regardless of mitigating factors.
Legislative provisions on capital offences must be strictly followed.

Treason.facts: The court considered the imposition of mandatory death sentences in capital offences beyond murder, specifically treason. The judgment examined constitutional debates around capital punishment and upheld the mandatory nature of the death penalty for treason.
Legal_Principle: Mandatory death penalty extends to treason under Kenyan law.

Legal_Principle: Treason prosecutions must balance state security and individual rights.

Treason.facts: The accused applied for bail while charged with a capital offence. The court denied bail citing the seriousness of capital offences, likelihood of flight, and public interest. The ruling reaffirms the principle that bail is rarely granted in capital offence cases.
Legal_Principle: Bail is generally denied in capital offences due to risk factors.
Public interest in justice and deterrence outweighs personal liberty in such cases.

Treason.facts: The accused challenged the application of the mandatory death sentence in treason cases. The court confirmed that the mandatory death sentence applies not only to murder but also to treason and similar capital offences, reinforcing statutory mandates.
Legal_Principle: Mandatory death sentence applies equally to murder, treason, and related capital offences.

Treason.facts: The accused was convicted of treason under Section 40(3) of the Penal Code. The court analyzed the statutory provisions, confirming that treason carries the severest penalties due to its threat to national security.

Treason.facts: The case focused on Section 123(1) of the Criminal Procedure Code, which mandates strict procedural and sentencing rules for capital offences like murder and treason. The court reinforced that these provisions ensure uniformity in handling capital offence trials.
Legal_Principle: Section 123(1) ensures procedural consistency for capital offences.
